Nose is rotten fruit under earth, sweet malt, weak almond, raisin, alcohol, feel is quite watery, carb is medium, taste is heavy red apple, very rounded alcohol, weak plum, acidid fruit finish with sweet mandarin notes
From a bottle in Brussels, Belgium august 2011. Brown, big tanned head. Licorice aroma. Tastes sweet  licorice, A nice beer.

Serving: 330 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a very dark brownish amber with a thick tan head.  Huge chunks poured out as it went into the glass.  There is a ton of shit floating around in this brew.  I have to admit, I am somewhat hesitant to try it.  The nose has notes of apple and pear cider, spice, yeast, and mace.  The flavor is surprisingly chocolatey with a good bit of sweetness and complexity.  A subtle berry fruitiness combines with the chocolate notes to make a very flavorful brew.  There is some vanilla and port qualities that come out as it warms.  The alcohol is there but not overwhelming.  Really quite good.  Medium to rich in body with lots of reasonably smooth carbonation.  Definitely a different kind of brew.  Major points for the flavor but major points off for the look and feel.  Having chunks hit your tongue while drinking is an unexpected and unwanted experience in my book.
Dark brown / red colored beer. Smell caramel and some spices, not really nice in my opinion. Decent taste, though not impressive. Good carbo, medium to full body.

33 cL bottle at Sheffield Tap into its own glass.  Lovely dark brown colour with red when held up to the light.  Nice head but it fades fast.  Tastes meaty, with hints of caramel and toffee.  Also something a bit rougher, like melted plastic.  Smells meaty and fruity.  Rather nice but also peculiar.  Chocolatey with a hint of nut.  Great and spectacularly odd, with some alcohol burn.

Originally rated August 2006. Sampled at Vineyards in Ottawa, Ontario. Poured a brown-amber-red colour with slight pink in it. The medium head had decent retention with mild lacing. Pretty big chunks (of yeast ?) were floating all around. A very beautiful nose of candy, mint, dark fruit and citrus. The mouthfeel was smooth, with absolutely no burn. The taste was good, because it did not overpower the dark fruit. Also found was some mild nuts, light mint, roasted malt and chocolat. Wow ! An extremely enjoyable brown Belgian strong ale that I strongly recommend.

8/15/11. 750mL bottle. Deep, cloudy clay brown pour with a small fizzy tan head that is gone instantly and doesnt lace at all. Interesting aroma of tart grapes, yeast, and roast that reminds me of an abt 12. Stronger caramel/malty flavor that then lingers with grapes and yeast once more. Interesting and quite nice, really.
caramel, bread, and light alcohol aroma,golden, light brown foam,light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long nice finish.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2011 Lots to like if you go for full, malty, moderately sweet beers. This beer is just a great example of a dark Belgian ale. Lots of complex flavor with pronounced raisin and plum, slightly spicy. Has the slight tanginess that I love in Belgian dark ales in the middle and finish. Finishes lightly sweet with a great aroma coming through at the end. This is a highly rated ale that did not disappoint. Right now, this is my favorite Belgian ale. Flawless.

Pours a dark murky copper with a generous head that dissipates quite quickly. Aroma is chestnuts, chocolate, wood, orange and caramel, my mouth started watering as I was smelling it. Taste is well balanced, a slight bitterness blends well with the sweet and floral elements. Flavour is citrus, caramel, chocolate with a hint of oak.

Pours a clear, dark brown red.  A slow gusher, giving a thick beige head.  Aroma is very caramel malty, a bit nutty.  Taste is a mature sweetness, medium heavy body.  Raisins, dark caramel, nuttiness, slightly salty.  Good creamy carbonated mouthfeel.  Nice bitterness throughout, expecting a lingering aftertaste, but the finish is dry and pretty abrupt.  A well crafted ale.
330ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Outstanding, toasted caramel tasting. Big alcohol aroma... nice.
Bottle @ Gastropub Tuulensuu, Tampere. Originally rated on 27.8.2010. Excellent, well balanced and complex Belgian strong ale.

Bottle, courtesy of yngwie.Pours deep amber with a small off-white head, some yeast in suspension.Aroma is fruity, malty and toasted.Flavor is sweet and malty with some warmth, yeast, caramel, berries and spice.Medium to full body, average carbonation. Nice malty beer.
Bottle. Muddy amber/brown colour with large creamy off-white mostly lasting head. Malty and yeasty aroma. Spicy notes. Sweet spicy flavor. Creamy palate.

Pouring into a Chimay glass.  Tons of carbonation.  Nice brownish gold color.  Smells of sweet yeast.  Tastes a malty caramel.
Definitely will be having this many times in the future

Bottled. Red-brown colour, with a beautiful fluffy foam. Sweet aroma, reminiscent of a flowery meadow. Maltsweet, with notes of banana, herbs and spices, with berry-ish tones and almond paste. No bitterness. Red apples. Big, complex flavour. Very enjoyableand perfect to sip slowly. The high ABV is hardly noticable. A good autumn beer.

Bottle. Golden dark red color, beautiful off-white head that hangs around for an impressively long time; it stays beautiful. Aroma has very sweet, rosy and fruity notes. It has pear, lots of spice, oak, floral yeast, flowers, deep notes of wet wood, strawberry and some syrupy stuff. Very nice balance with plenty of fruits carried on a warm alcohol note. Taste is velvety and soft, almost without carbonation, quite deeply fruity with lots of sweet berries, strawberry, burnt caramel, toasted wood, raisins and plums. Very good balance, perhaps lacking a bit of carbonation to freshen it up on the palate. Very good, though.

Bottle from Olkonsortiet cons 2011-06-06
Gooser
AR: vinos, dadels, filling malty aromas
AP: cloudy dark brown/reddish body, wee ofwhitehead
F:  vinos, dadels, filling malty aromas, plumcake, dry & fruity finish

Poured from a bottle into a Bruery tulip. Lots of sediment in this one. Luckily I have a strong constitution.

Beer is brown, dark, and really hazy with chunks floating in it. Brown thin dusty head, medium bubbles, nice lacing, strong forward carbonation.

Aroma sweet and bready. Mild, good though.

Beer is pretty sweet. Lots of carbonation on the palate, some caramel flavors, breadiness and esters on the midpalate, finish is a little dry, not too much though. Overall a nice beer.

Serving type: bottle

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2012 A murky brown body with an off white head. Aroma is complex but quite sweet with brown sugar and plum most notably. Flavour is sweet with fruits, plum, sugar and apricot. Very good, but not overly impressed. (7/4/8/4/17)
Murky brown body with a creamy off white head. Sweet aroma with caramel, brown sugar, spices and plum. Smooth, well carbonated palate. Dark fruits, spices and brown sugar in the sweet but balanced flavour.

My label is exactly like this except is says Brasserie instead of Abbaye.  Brown with not much head at all - not very carbonated.  Lots of dark fruit flavors, especially cherries, mixed with tons of malt softness.  Very good, but tough to have a whole bottle of this by yourself.

330ml bottle while waiting for dinner at Den Heeren van Liedekercke. Nicely served in a special glass. Beige patches on the surface of a dark ruby brown body. Chocolate and caramel malts to the nose with a touch of spiced fruits. Fine blended taste of dark and dried fruits. Warming alcohol to a lingering bittersweet ending. Well built, enjoyable beer  (Denderleeuw. 01.05.2011).
2011 - 06 - 01 330ml bottle. dark brown colour. medium creme head. sweet and roasted, herable taste. alcohol slightly present.

colore è un rosso ramato, con sfumature prugna, schiuma ampia e compatta, aroma di frutta rossa, lieviti e malti, in bocca è fruttata, dolce di caramello, con vaghe note di luppoli che tendono a riequilibrare la beva, retrogusto lungo, piacevole e caldo.

750ml bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy dark ruby brown with a medium head.  Aroma is plum and sweet raisin.  Some slight sour notes.  Taste starts with Ribenna.  Could be a bit fuller for the strength.  Plum and alcohol on the finish with some raisin on the finish.
Bottle. Pours red brown with a beige head. Plummy dark fruity aroma with toasted bread, and light spices. The flavor is sweet malty and dark fruity, with spicy yeasty, peach, plums, and bread. Nice.

Contemplative and broody.  Murky brown with a small head. Wonderful aroma, dark fruit, caramel, sour with orange and plum. Flavour of raisin, plum, caramel, fruity with some plum and some mild sourness. Soft body and full palate with restrained carbonation.

Big thanks to ygtbsm94 for sharing a bottle of the 2006 vintage of this. Also had a separate bottle more recently, at which time I took better notes. Review from those.

Served in a wine glass. Gushed quite a bit, overflowing after I opened it. It was probably a bit too warm. Loads of floaties, though this is quite explainable given the gushing. Pours brown-garnet with a moderate head that quickly falls into a collar with a speckled cap. The nose is strong, earthy red grapes with some caramel and plum in the background. there are also some other dark fruits and a good measure of sweetness as well.

The taste is not quite as complex but there are strong grapes and a bit of cherries. This is quite sweet but never cloying. There is a bit of darker malt in the background; no roast. The feel is medium and cream. Light--though very fitting--level of carbonation. Incredibly drinkable. Likely my new go to Belgian beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-29-2010

Bouteille de 330ml. Gugher, la bière se mis à mousser dès son ouverture, elle se vide rapidement dans la verre, les particules de levure qui étaient collées au fond de la bouteille se retrouvent jonchés sur la mousse beige qui est durable. Le liquide est brune. Le nez offre de beaux arômes de fruits et de levure. La bouche est soyeuse, ronde, épicées, lalcool est peu présent. On doit faire abstraction du visuel pour apprécié cette bière mais une fois fait...ouf on a affaire à une bière sublime. Cette bière sétait mérité un 9/10 il y a 15 ans, elle na pas changé.

dark amber body, a light tan head, ok retention... nose of too much alcohol but its also pretty sweet... taste is better, caramel, dark fruits, candied sugar and plums... nice full body... pretty good, wouldnt seek out but Id have again

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2011 (33 cl, bottle from JulienHuxley, Second bottle from SAQ, september 2011)  Le liquide dévoile une robe brune rougeâtre qui déborde de sédiments.  La petite tête mousseuse se retire rapidement et laisse sur son passage une belle dentelle.  Au nez, des notes fruitées complexes et en légère confiture  cerises, oranges, raisins et tellement dautres  enlacent des chocolatines et enrobent des bonbons épicés au caramel et au beurre de noisettes.  Le goût est suave, très doux, sexprimant avec une lenteur contrôlée, peut-être altéré par son vieillissement, révélant après chaque gorgée des murmures  enrobées de chocolat et de fruits mûrs dans lesquelles apparaissent des flaveurs de mélasse qui se frottent à de très légers soubresauts aromatisés.  Lalcool est habilement caché, sa retenue est superbe.  En bouche, le liquide a une rondeur convenable avec une effervescence très peu vivante et une texture crémeuse.  La finale est forte de malts et de fruits, touchée par la réglisse et la tiédeur dun alcool sucré.  Que de bons mots pour cette bouteille qui a déjà pris quelques rides et qui mérite, dans cette perspective, dêtre revisitée.  (Évaluation différente, 4.1 à 4.4)

Dark red brown color with a lots of yeast pieces.Amazing biege head.Smell baked muffin,raisin,cloves,caramel,chocolate,spicy,tobac malts.orange.Taste bread,cream brulle,light chocolate,butter,sweet,overripe fruits,plums,spices,mango,caramelized nuts, hint of brandy, Good champagne mouthfeel.Great ballance.Nice bread,alcohol finish.a wonderful beer,so easy dreaking.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2014 Pours brown with alot of floaty stuff in it. Aroma of dates, caramel, dark malts, prunes and raisins. Taste add a vinous sour character. dark fruits is also here along with the caramelish malts leading to some warming alcohol at the end.

13/03/2011 - 33cl bottle @ home - BB: 12/3/2013 (2011-116)  
Murky brown beer, small pieces of residu floating around. Light beige big and creamy head. Quite stable and non-adhesive. Aroma: caramel, apple skin, dried fruits, alcohol, chocolate, even a bit of mocha. MF: ok carbon, full body. Taste: fruity, caramel, red fruits, citrus fruits, bit of mocha. Aftertaste: turning somewhat more hop bitter, mocha and chocolate, with still a sour twist keeping it all very balanced. Mighty good beer. Im stocking up on this one!

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2013 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: gave me a winter beer impression, tasted of sweet malts, caramel, sugar, spices, liquorice with a small alcohol bite, resembled a quad little bit & gave me a trappist like impression, certainly not bad // I have been trying this again recently - no new review but increase score from 3.9 to 4.7 - incredibly complex & good // drank again, changing score from 4.7 to 4.9 - this is ridiculously good

330 ml bottle in Germany. Pours a red/brown color with a prolific head that lasts forever (you will finish this beer and then want to drink the remaining head). Aroma is complex, fruity, sweet with caramel and cooked plum, raisin and fig. You could spend an hour smelling this beer and still find new things with every smell. Flavor is equally complex and malty with a touch of wood that was not presant in the aroma. A wonderful, subtle, refined yet strong and dominating beer.
0,3 liter fles. Gekregen van annelies op onze 36 jarige trouwdag. Fantastisch goed bier. 9% alc en het heeft geen enkele alcohol smaak. Perfect.

Picked up a bottle while I was in Belgium.  Pours cloudy brown with a tan head.  Massive amount of floaters, almost though I should have filtered it.  Belgian yeast, sweet fruit and malt in the aroma.  Great beer though.
UPDATED: FEB 20, 2011 Aroma: licorice, raisins, malt, nuts. Sweet and a bit wood in taste. Nice red in appearance with ok head. Lively carbonation. A beer full of aroma and flavors.

750ml from Secret Santa  damn, I got hooked up!  Pours murky chocolate brown with some floaters and a one finger light tan head.  The nose is caramel, fruity esters and spicy yeast.  The taste is sweet fruits, rich caramel and rock candy.  Medium mouthfeel.  Very complex.  8/4/8/3/17

forse una birra troppo impegnativa visto il mio recente approccio al mondo birraio!cmq intanto ci provo!colore trai il marrone e lambrato con qualche riflesso rubino bella schiuma sottile cremosa di media persistenza,torbida con sedimenti galleggianti!allinizio lho bevuta un po troppo fresca e sia laroma che il gusto erano subito sul luppolo ma comunque con un grandissimo equilibrio!ribevuta dopo una mezzora ad una temperatura un po piu alta e allolfatto si sentiva gia di piu lalcool il malto tostato un pizzico di arancia e pepe!in bocca leggero cioccolato alla vaniglia spezie e man mano che scende in gola anche un po di prugna e liquirizia!è sparito un po il luppolo ad una temperatura piu alta ed il retrogusto era piu sul malto tostato!a distanza di minuti in bocca si ripresentano ad uno ad uno tutti i sapori precedentemente descritti.molto buona anche se al secondo bicchiere un po diventava pesante forse per via di un sapore troppo speziato che contrasta con lalcool!

33 cL bottle at Smokeless Joe in Toronto, served in a snifter. Pours hazy red-brown with some sediment and a medium, dense frothy tan head. The head remains to the end and leaves a moderate amount of fine lace. The nose has huge fruit aromas, with apple and sour cherry, along with raisins, brown sugar, maple syrup and cask wood. The flavour is intensely fruity sweet with caramel, maple syrup and raisins. There is a hint of sour apple and a touch of hops towards the end. The finish is long and malty. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, an amazing Belgian ale with an intense fruity sweetness, complex malts and lots of nuance. A new favourite! 2011-01-27
Splendido colore marrone scuro con schiuma persistente. Aroma caldo di cioccolato amaro, ma non invadente. In bocca è perfettamente equilibrata tra malto e luppolo.

Bottle picked up at StateLine. I have never seen chunks this big in a beer before...but this beer has them. It looked like small peanut size floaties while I was pouring the beer. Nice brown color....It was a gusher... exploding in to foam soon as I popped the top. Funky aroma of some green apples, malty and sugary... A little tartness on the nose. Taste is nice... Creamy smooth... Well balanced. Some malty notes, moss/peat, sugar (but not sweet at all), some wood flavor. Texutre is perfect.... creamy smooth. Overall: Besides all the floaties nothing wrong with this beer.....another great belgian brew

New Beer Distributors 11.2oz ($3.50): Pours a reddish mahogany color with a creamy looking beige head. Molasses and a whole lot of dark fruits, including grapes (not quite sure what currants smell like to I cant comment on them). Some slightly burned malts in there as well. Medium to full-bodied, but not quite syrupy. Beer goes through phases in the mouth, with distinct beginning, middle, and finish. Alcohol entirely covered by the complexity of flavor. Brown sugar, some rum, malts, malts, malts. Hard for me to find the hops in there... A big beer (albeit not exactly my favorite style of Beligan Strong Ale...), that is undeniably well-crafted.

33 cl bottle, pours ruby with a nice big head that has super retention, aroma of yeast, dark fruits, caramel, dough and sugar, taste follows the nose, slightly burnt mouthfeel,  good but not great finish, solid beer.

TOP 100 TICK, I LOVE IT!!!  330ml bottle via trade thanks to Crack1Open on BA.  Pours hazy brown, a little reddish,
with a small khaki head.  The aroma is nice, with caramel, toffee,
brown sugar, belgian yeast, and slight dark fruits.  The flavor is
sweet but good, with big caramel malts, English toffee, sherry-like
oxidation, Belgian yeast, and berries, blueberries even as crazy as
that is.  Medium-full body with lower carbonation.  Solid stuff, even
if its possibly a little past prime.

Pours ruby clowdy brown with heavy cediment. The bottle "squirted" a bit resulting to a quick pour to begin with. Pretty dense tanned head leaving some lanice lacing. Aroma is fullbalanced malty, fruity, raisins, prunes, syrup & dark sugar and vanilla with noticable tones of alcohol; very complex but yet fantasticly good. Fresh mouthfeel. Acidy fullbodied palate.Finishes malty sweet and tart hoppy.

I dont give many 10s, in any component, but this beer deserves one in Taste. This bruin is just amazing. Sweet and delectable, with tastes of ripened dark fruit, honey-sweetness, just unbelievable. Complex, tasty, and actually very reasonably priced. A true classic.

0.33l Bottle.  Pours deep reddish brown.  Aroma is complex with yeast, oranges, and floral the predominant notes.  Taste is wonderfully rich with orange, raisin, and bread standing out with hints of alcohol and clove on top of a subtle but solid hop base.

Rating #456, bottle brought by Brian, so it is probably bought in Fish n Beer, but I dont know for sure  

This is an opaque red-brown beer with a nice head. Aroma is belgian-style with yeast, flowers, oranges, hops and a certain sourishness. Luckily, the flavor was oranges, raspberries, elderberries, soap, yeast and flowers with a finish of  light hops followed with a bit of pepper - very nice, and definately one of the belgian ales living up to the aroma. Creamy and soft palate, but there is a bit too much carbonation for perfection. Very nice belgian brew, though!
Bread, yeast, dried fruits, quite sweet, like candy sugar, complex. Nice beer.

750ml bottle, best by 4/29/12, from CBX. pours a hazy, reddish-copper with big chunks of yeast and a huge, rocky, off-white head leaving a thick meshwork of lace. aroma is great, very different, with big, tart, fruit notes of vinous red grapes, blackberries, and cherries with a touches of lemon zest and orange juice backed by sweet, belgian yeast, honey, light toffee, and wood with a myriad of spices and soapy florals. flavor is outstanding with a cornucopia of fruit notes including plum, apricot, red apple, fig, and raisin backed by sweet, yeasty gingerbread, belgian spices, and caramel with hints of honey-covered rice cereal, cedar, earthy hops, and nutty fruitcake on the back end. palate is full bodied with lively carbonation and a dry, sweet finish. overall, a great belgian strong.

Bottle from Beer Planet, Brussels. Deep, clear copper body with a lacy, khaki-colored creamy head which lingers on the side of my Trappist bowl. Aroma is raisins, nuts, black currants and dark malts. Taste is raisins again, nougat, raspberries and malt sugars. Smooth palate, and very drinkable with a low-profile ABV. An interesting combo of fruitiness and the classical "bruin" feeling makes Abbaye des Rocs Brune a pretty interesting abbey ale. Particularly, the black currants in the aroma and the fruity hints of raspberry-ish berries in the taste are both perfectly blended in with the rest. A very good beer, although I somehow longs for it to be slightly more adventurous in some way.

08-01-10: Brune, touble, avec une mousse éphémère. Au nez, dintenses arômes fruités dorange, de cassonade et de caramel. Dintensité moyenne, elle offre des saveurs de sucre et dalcool, ainsi que dorange caramélisé. Trop sucrée, elle fini par taper sur le coeur. Décevante.

Bottle, tfs Vaiz! Murky brown, orange glow, large off white head. Aroma is yeasty fruit, some malt and spices.
Flavour is medium sweet and bitter, fruity, yeasty.
Expected more.

Bottle. Pours a deep murky brown / orange with more then a slight amount of yeast. Robust and thick tan head with good lacing all the way through my drink. The nose is sweet, caramel and rich fruit. The mouth has distinct alcohol. Dark and fruity. Nice brew.

What a disappointment, this brew is. Being rated this high, I expected a lot, it however smells like normal abbey dubbel and tastes like some aged barley wine. Loads of ripe fruits and sweetness and very smooth, but nothing special to me. It does remind me of other highly acclaimed brews which I didnt like so it seems this category is simply not for me.
Aroma of plum covered lavender, sour apple, ripe red grape and boozy cherries. Appearance is dark red murky body with frothy tan head. Flavor matches the nose. Palate is bubbly and creamy. Wow.

Reddish brown, great flocks of yeast in the glass, although layered and pooured quietly. Dense big off-white head.Aroma is malty, sweetish, a bit of coffee, somewhat spices. Slightly bitter taste, sweetish, caramel, medium bodied with a quick diminishing finish, with some cholcolate in it.

Aged one year.
Pours copper/ruby, lots of floating yeast, small off-white head.
Nose is very sweet, loads of golden syrup, brown sugar, toffee, bread and candi sugar. Some soft phenols provide further complexity.
Flavours are very similar, more bready notes though. Still intensely sweet, but hardly any noticeable alcohol, just a little bite on the finish to counter the sweetness.
Moderate carbonation but very fine and smooth; fits the beer well.

Served into a Unibroue snifter

A: Red brownish almost like tea, beige foam that stays for a while leaving a pearly lace. some visible carbonation.

S: Sweet, dark malts, floral, alcohol, hops, brown sugar.

T: Sweet and floral, little bit bitter, warming but not overwhelming, brown sugar, carbonation feel.

Overall an excellent beer (that its going to be in rotation for a while in my house), it has a lot of layers,  I had in two different occasions after I made my first review and the flavors developed a  bit.

(330 ml bottle @ Gastropub Tuulensuu. Rated @ 27.8.2010.)
Brown colour with a beige head. Complex aroma with notes of wood, dark fruits and nuts. Chocolate, caramel, fruits and syrup on the taste. Fair amount of yeast too. Medium bodied, creamy texture and the alcohol is well-hidden. Really nice brew.

Pours deep dark red with significant yeast sediment, a nice bubbly white head.  Aroma of raisin and plume with a touch sweet bread. Med-high sweetness with a light bitterness that hangs in there.  Medium bodied, with a creamy texture form the high carbonation, no noticable alcohol or warmth from this beer..  An excellent beer that is very smooth, drinkable, yet dangerous at 9%.  A great after dinner beer, hell it will go great with dinner or even before dinner.  Top 10 for me!
Murky brown, quick fizzy off white foam.  Aroma is malty, fig, candy sweet.  Taste is more sweet malt, fig, caramel, bread.

75 cl bottle. Promising aroma and great looking brown colour with white head, but I expected more body from a 9% beer. light soy and sour flavours along with a gentle maltyness. Not as good as I remember it being in the past, but perhaps superseded by new brewing from the US, Scandanavia and the Netherlands.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a lot of head.  Spicy sweet malty flavor with a quick finish.

This poured a medium brown color with an off white head. Aroma was very sweet lightly roasted malt and some medium candy sugar. Flavor was very sweet, dark fruits, candy sugar, some yeast and all around belgian goodness.

At a tasting, thanks DSG, 5-6 years old bottle, pours brown with a huge head, aroma of plums, raisins, orange, orange skin, cherry liquor and wood, flavors of hay, smoked malt, pleasant acidity, tender plum sweetness, watery texture and a medium body, probably past its peak yet a nice brew.
Bottle 33 cl. Brown, cloudy with a huge lightbrown head. Aroma; Fruity, malt, chocolate, caramel, plumb, complex and nice... TAste; Sweet with a soft sence of alcohol at the end. NICE§

At a tasting, bottled in 2004, thanks DSG,  no head, murky light brown colour, strong aroma of bread, apricot, cola and a hint of honey, flavours of apricot, nactarine, caramel and some spiciness, strong dominating, sourness reaching out to the aftertaste.

From old notes: Bottle at Bar Volo, Pours slightly hazy golden amber with offwhite head; Aroma of sweet roasted malt and dried fruit and spice; Flavour is malt sweetness, dried fruit and caramel; Lingering aftertaste with warming alcohol noticeable

Bottle, compliments of my son, Keith (fata2683) poured into a tulip glass produced a dark amber body with hints of red and a tall, foamy tan head that dissipated quickly.   Aroma is fruity with some plum, cherries, grapes and caramel.  Dominant flavors were pineapple, white grapes, cherries, and brown sugar.  Light and crisp finish.  Quite sweet but delicious.

Bottle...  Poured deep brown, reddish/maroon with a thin head, lots of yeast floaties.  Aroma was sugary, cereal malts, dark, plump fruits.  Tasted of raisins, nice tannins, gingersnaps, with a light yeast tartness that offered a dry finish.  Hints of roasted, candied nuts. A little bit of hop spiced, zest.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of dark dried fruits, bread, sweet malts and ginger.  Medium brown hue with an average sized head that mostly diminished.  Flavor starts sweet and finishes smooth and a little musty.  Palate is medium bodies and creamy soft.  Overall a good, tasty brew.  Great example of the style and quite affordable.

Reddish brown with big clumps of gunge (the second glass is more soup than beer even on a careful pour). After trying to climb out of the bottle a little, head fades to a stable thick beige coat with lovely lacing. Aroma of nuts and caramel, figs, prunes, raisins and a strange melange of spice/ earth/ fruit/ grass hops and yeast - very complex and beautifully integrated as a whole. Taste has upfront alcohol over fruity and caramel sweetness with some backing bitterness. Taste is not as good as the aroma suggested - its merely excellent. Syrupy mouthfeel. A very good beer with an off-the-charts aroma.

750ml and 11.2oz bottle.  This one split with DarkBeerChick.  Pours a dark brown with reddish highlights and a good bit of tan, lasting head.  Lots of floaties in this bottle as all the brunes Ive had.  Aroma is candi sugar, fig preserves, Belgian yeast and brown sugar coated baked pears.  Flavor follows the aromas and also adds dark fruits, medium sweetness and loads of malty-ness.  Medium body and mouthfeel.  Apart from those odd yeast clumps, this shit absolutely rocks.  Its available everywhere and is reasonably priced.  Try it, youll like (or love) it!!  Rating #1000 for this beer.

pours a deep hazy brown.  Caramel and dark fruits on the nose.  Taste is quite sweet with the aroma also coming through in the taste.  Has a candy-like taste and stickiness.  also has a sweet bread component.  Overall a very nice brew indeed.

33 cl bottle, shared with Hanspanzer og Sølve. Thanks, Sølve. Brown, light copper color, fine off-white head. Aroma is fruity and sweet malty. Flavor is fruit and lovely balanced sweetness from the malt and medium bitterness. Very smooth in the mouth. Lovely!

La migliore abbaye des rocs finora provata, dopo la blanche des honnelles e la montagnarde. Moltissimi residui solidi anche percepibili in bocca, ma questa è davvero lunica pecca: tutto il resto è perfetto, dalla schiuma, beigetta e solidissima, al profumo di fiori, al sapore di malto e miele. Ottima

Dark amber/ruby color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, toffee, caramel, & dark fruit; Flavor of slight roasted sweet malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit (notably plums), raisons, toffee, and spicy hops at the finish; Nicely balanced and quite complex; A different and unique brew - very good overall.

Ill be one to buck the trend here, I dont see the attraction of this beer at all. To be fair perhaps this beer was aged too long (though that would hardly seem the case) as it was aged around 2.5 years. The beer pours out a light brown with a quick head that quickly goes away, aroma was pretty awful to be honest super yeasty and booze was about all I could pick up even after 5 minutes of letting it sit in my trappist glass. Appearance isnt that great either head retention problems for sure and massive floaties are everywhere in this beer. Tasting the beer yeilds more and more booze followed by sweet and spicy yeast notes that are typical of Belgian beers but this one just seemed over the top. Significant sugars all over the place that dont seem to blend well, body is fairly thin for the style, and on top of that you get a distrubing feeling everytime one of those floaties grazes your teeth. I will try this again but for now this one is getting hammered by me.

12 oz bottle, aprox 2 years old. caramel nose. flavor is light sweetness, with sharp fruity notes-rasin and apricot. slightyly sticky, linger flavor. some alcohol in the very smooth finish. i was this beer was more widely disrupted here, beacuse id drink it all the time.

From 11 oz bottle. Labeled "Brasserie des Rocs." Aroma super-deep dark fruit though a little under-complex. Deep brown color; great head retention; huge chunks of yeast. Flavor is mostly raisin and dark fruit; the 10% is not at all evident. Medium body, slick, silky, medium-stick; wonderful body. Very nice but not quite St. Bernardus 8 in my opinion.

The beer pours a medium brown color with a cream-colored head. There are huge chunks of yeast that come out of the bottle. (I also got this is then Grand Cru from this brewery.) Not very appetizing. The aroma is brown sugar and dark fruit. The flavor is dark fruit, alcohol, brown sugar, yeast and some darker malts. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Pours a deep amber red with a thin foam head.  Has some life to it.  Has an aroma of dark fruit, malt, and yeast.  Just a more refined version of the Grand Cru.  A very bready, yeasty beer, with a sweet dark fruit flavor.  This beer is not balance enough, nor complex enough.  Very dissapointed in this brewery thus far.

750ml bottle from IPB
Apparence : Clear amber with a white head. Nice lacing.

Aroma : Nicely sweet and spicy with fruits (peaches I think)

Taste : Spicy and fruity.

Overall : Awesome fruity nose. Really nice sweetness. Taste is quite spicy and feels a bit simple however. I liked the Triple Imperiale a lot more.

Infected bottle. Pours muddy brown with lots of sediment I had to pour through a strainer. Beer still had molasses and brown sugar aroma. Taste is same, but muted with some plum--a relic of a once great beer.

33cl bottle. Poured orange/mahogany with a small beige head that was peppered with chunks of brown particles... large chunks of white particles were in the beer itself. Aroma: spices, roasted caramel, fruit, malt & roasted malt, over-ripe/sweet sourness... other things going on but unable to be sure what. Taste: amazingly balanced mix of roasted caramel, sweet malts, notes of booze & fresh fruit, honey, ripe plums, spices. Creamy mouth feel, mild carbonation. Nice finish with just a touch of alcohol warmth. Overall a great beer: full body, great depth, complex, great balance.

Pours a cloudy ruby-mahogany with a small white head that quickly fades to film. The aroma is Full of plum, toffee, caramel, green apple, and light roast. The flavor hold the same traits, with a bit of woodiness and an interesting, almost tart finish with hop bitterness. Very smooth and almost wine-like, with a lot of well blended flavors.
Contrary to the majority, I really dont care for this beer. A little too bitter for the style. Not enough fruitiness not sweet enough.  For a Belgian strong ale Ill stick with Duval.

Bottle 33cl. A deep brown ale with a head that disappeard quickly, carbonation is high. Smell is powerful with lot of spices, its more on christmas beers. Aroma is dense, fruits notes as oranges and dark fruits, quite spicy with notes of cloves and green pepper, malty character  is more on caramel side. Medium sweet with brown candy aroma. Bitterness is medium, a bit acid at the finish. Typical belgian yeast  taste with fruit notes (esters). Very nice beer that reminds me the Rochefort one, very enjoyable.
Translucent headless brownish red, aroma of wine and black cherries. Flavor is of cherries, prunes, malt, and slight vinegar on the palate. Bottle from Stop and Shop Miami.

33 cl Bottle. Pours a mohogany brown with a small head that doesnt last long. Aroma is malty and yeasty with banana, apple, dried cherry. Flavor is malty sweet with a hint of roasted nuttiness that precedes the acidity in the finish.  Alcohol is well hidden. Body is very full with a smooth mouthfeel.

Bottle. Color, deep red beer with a fantastic light brown head. Aroma is sweet and fruity, very complex. Taste is very fruity, with prune, toffee with caramel and light bitter long finish. Excellent beer, one of my favorites.

Bottle. Pours dark red with a lasting off-white head. Aroma of dried fruits, sweet plums, spiced bread. The flavour is bread, caramel, dried fruits and some spice. Superbly balanced with a big fruity finish. Very nice indeed.

Botle. Pours a dark brownish red with a small and fast diminishing beige head. Aroma of rich fruits, caramelised pears, sweet malt and anise. Flavour is very malty and yeasty with some cocoa bitterness. There is a slight sourness from the yeast that shows through. Slightly hidden alcohol but it is warming which gives this a nice full body. Well balanced and complex with a satisfying and long-lasting finish.

Pours a reddish brown with a thin white head that lasted less than a minute for me.  I must have smelled this beer 30 times - raisins, figs and dried, candied pineapples.  Tastes just like it smells, with the addition of a fourth taste: a bit of cherry juice.  Medium and and oily with some soft carbonation, this Belgian is very sweet.  I like it, but its so sweet that I would share the next 11.2 ounce bottle with a friend or two.

Bottle sent to me via a busted side bet on the Super Bowl thanks to dmac. I took this to a friends and on the way had to slam on the brakes. The bottle went flying and it didnt break. What did happen sort of reminded me of a snow globe. All the yeast was floating around like a snow blizzard in Jersey. I decided to let this one rest for a good hour while we sipped on a few others. The first pour from the snow globe Jersey blizzard beer was quite nice. Only a few floaties. But that wasnt my pour. My brother in law took that one. The second pour was reminescent of what I saw in the bottle after my braking incident in the car.  I sat and starred at my glass thinking about how miserable it must really be for newbies to look at a glass like this and think drain pour. My experience has taught me otherwise. I sipped the beverage knowing what was in store and enjoyed every last drop of my chunky refreshment. I even tasted my Bros and it wasnt much different. Although he swore my snow globe beer tasted funny. Great stuff!

Amber beer with a tight white head, strong alcoholic edge and a taste of pineapple. A strong Belgian Dark Ale with a gentle malty foundation and a lingering warming alcohol finish. Double fermented with 7 types of malts and three kinds of hops (Belgian, German and Czech). At 9% it is potent but satisfying.

2.	Bouteille 330ml. De couleur brune-rouge et voilée. Nez de levures très fruitées (prunes, raisins, figues, léger de cerises et traces dagrumes), malté de caramel sucré avec des notes de sucre brun, légèrement épicé (clou de girofle) et avec des notes de chocolat noir et des traces dalcool. Ronde-moyenne en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture riche et moyennement crémeuse. Goût de levures fruitées sucrées (prunes, léger de raisins aux notes vineuses, léger de pomme rouges, notes dagrumes, traces de figues) avec de légères notes épicées (clou de girofle) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté de caramel  avec des notes de sucre brun et de pain ainsi que de faibles traces de chocolat et de mélasse sucrée puis en finale lon retrouve une légère amertume de houblon herbeux ainsi quun léger goût dalcool sucré (traces de rhum) et des notes de levures épicées (petit goût poivré). Post-goût long, moyennement amer dalcool doux et léger de houblon herbeux avec un goût de levures fruitées (pelures de prune et léger moût de raisins)

Bottle.

A - Dark murky brown with a lot of sediment floating in this beer. Large light brown head with pretty good retention.

S - Dark fruit and sugary smell upfront. Also some spices (Cinnamon and pepper). Along with the dark fruit there is some malty/caramel scents.

T - Fairly sweet between the dark fruit, dark sugar, and malt. Balanced a bit by some of the spices in this beer. There is a bit of nuttiness to the taste as well. Alcohol is pretty well hidden although it gives off a fortified wine kind of taste.

M - Probably would be medium bodied but relative to what I would expect it is a bit thin, decent carbonation though.

D - Really tasty and would like to drink a couple of these. Only thing that is holding that off is the ABV, and that after 2 or 3 it might be a little sweet.

Notes: Liquid alcoholic candy might be a little off (I dont think it is that sweet), but that description wouldnt be too off. A very nice Belgian.

(750ml bottle best by 12/17/2011) pours deep reddish amber with lasting head and great lacing. Nose of Belgian yeast, Candi sugar, brown sugar, apples, pears and other fruits. Taste of golden raisins, Candi/beet sugar, very bready/yeasty. Medium body, perfect carbonation and long sweet duration.

I had one of these several years ago and was unimpressed. So its brother sat in my cellar for several years, unappreciated. It turned into a malty, yeasty bomb that compares well with the likes of Rochefort 8 and Westvleteren 8.  Delicious.

di un bellissimo colore rosso cupo,il suo aroma ricorda quello del vino,caldo e avvolgente,dal finale decisamente fruttato.
sicuramente non è proprio la mia birra ideale,ma devo riconoscere che è una brra da provare assolutamente!

Deep blood red in colour with a stable, slightly off-white head. The aroma just bursts of peach fruitiness, dried fruits like figs and raisins and fumes of alcohol. The flavour is really malty, chocolatey and biscuity with a strong dark caramel backbone and a rather crisp, slightly roasty finish. Just tons of malts in this beer. The carbonation is soft, making it highly drinkable while maintaining a full palate. A really nice, classic belgian here.
75 cl bottle. Hazy dark red-brown body with medium size white head. Flavour is malt, hops, fruit and spices.

33cl bottle. Hazy amber to brown color with lots of sediment and a creamy white head. Aroma has some dark sugar, lots of malt, some fruit and a touch of yeast. The taste is malty with some fruit and hop and a decent bitterness. The body is full and the mouthfeel is a little bit sticky. A very nice brew.

Bottle, York Beer and Wine Shop. Bottle. Poured a hazy  chestnut brown colour with a half decent tan head. Aroma had notes of caramel malt, dark fruit, leather and nuts. Slid down clean and smooth. Slightly sweet flavour with notes of brown sugar and fruit, some vague belgian yeast lurking in the shadows. Nice bit of hoppiness there too that led to a dry finish. Good one. 

.
Bottle. Very dark brown-red, nice head, but dont hold very long. Heavy taste, some fruit-touch. Good one.
Bottle pour.Amber colored with a medium white head.Sweet aroma mixed with some dark fruits.Taste was the same,sweetness,dark fruits with hints of yeast spice.Very drinkable brew.

Bottle, 33 cl. Dark brown beer with a red shine and a little white head that stays. Aroma is malty, caramel and light sweet. Malty taste, chocolate, light sweet and halfway light hoppy. A very nice beer again of Abbaye Des Rocs!
750 ml bottle a dark brown colored beer with a white head aroma dark fruit yeast spices and hops taste dry fruit spices some hints of alcohol and a hoppy finish very good beer

Bottle graciously split by Shyam.  Nose is very earthy with dark fruit, mellow purple Belgian yeast, faint German hops, a whisper of rauch character.  Color is a hazy glossy brown blood.  Flavor rivals the very best quads: rich bread pudding, mulled plum, faint wood, more of that classic dark fruit/yeast combination.  Worth the wait, and now, sadly, I cannot wait to find more.

Bottle pours a dark amber color with light head.  Lots of sediment in the bottom of my glass, shouldnt have let the bottle tip over on the drive over.  Strong complex aroma of fruit and caramel.  Taste is a little sweet with tons of fruits and complexity.  Medium to full body with creamy mouthfeel.  This is an elite beer, one of my favorites.
dark brown coloured body with a off white head  a spicy fruity malty aroma a spicy malty fruity sweet taste with a sweet alcholic bitter finish

33cl  bottle, dark amber colour, lots of yeast floating, creamy persistent beige head, complex aroma of caramel, liquorice and fruits (plum, peach and raisins), honey sweet flavor, full body, dry finish with yeast and some alcohol, orange notes aftertaste, amazing beer for say goodbye to 2009
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2009 Light but very tasty brown ale. Sweetness is held back, giving way to lots of complexity. Flavors of caramel, liquorice. Dry finish. Excellent.

Hazy amber big white head, lasting... Big notes of cherry in both the aroma and flavor, not very carbonated, a touch boozy, complexly aromatic, medium bodied, dry finish, a touch hoppy throughout, intensely complex, huge notes of fruits and malts, with an element of belgian yeastiness underlying but not dominating... World Class...
Brown coloured beer with small white head and lots of carbonation. Malty roasted aroma. Full sparkling palate. Finish is roasted bitter. Nice one.

Shared this one w/ SkyCop32.  Pours a darkish red/brown. Aromas of spice, coriander, yeast, and alcohol. Flavor has an alcohol taste to it, mixed with a nice smokey dark fruit. Also has strong hints of spice and orange.

Green bottle, 750 ml, best before December 2010, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savoured on December 19 2009; eye: bronze, clear, no effervescence, tiny ring of beige head, light lacing; nose: malt, tobacco, tired, fruity, light caramel, light rum, molasses; mouth: malt, tobacco, tired, fruity, light caramel, light alcohol, light rum, molasses, finale in malt with presence of caramel, medium body, not much carbonation, lightly sweet, slick texture; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille verte, 750 ml, meilleure avant décembre 2010, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savourée le 19 décembre 2009; il : bronze, claire, pas deffervescence, petit anneau de mousse beige, légère dentelle; nez : malt, tabac, « fatigué », fruité, léger caramel, léger rhum, mélasse; bouche : malt, tabac, « fatigué », fruité, léger caramel, léger alcool, léger rhum, mélasse, finale en malt avec présence de caramel, corps moyen, peu carbonatée, légèrement sucrée, texture coulante; en résumé : bien

Dark amber/brown color, light brown head. Very complex aroma: malty, fruity and a bit spicy. Alchoolic. 
A wonderful sweetness with a nice carbonation. Medium to full body.
Just a bit of bitter in the end balances the taste. Cannot find wrong points in this beer. A must to drink in my opinion.

Pours a burnt red with a modest amount of carbonation and a creamy white head. This bear possesses an interesting variety of flavors and aromas. There is a prominent aroma of malt with some underlying notes of hops and prunes. The taste is an interesting blend of malt, yeast, and noticeable banana. The brew is moderately thick and there is an unctuous residual flavor that is left on the palate.

Caramel, nuts, and toasted bread on the nose. This beer poured a phenomenal brown color with amazing lacing and head retention. It has TONS of floaties and just seeing this beer made me even thirstier. Dont even get me started on the taste...superior craftsmanship with sweet, caramel, clove, and general amazingness. Smooth on the palate and sweet after taste. Overall this is hands down the best brown ale Ive ever had.

Small bottle 2008 vintage. Muddy brown pour with thin white head. Buttery, nutty, sweet aromas. Some caramel toffey flavors, more hazelnuts. Nice sugars. Rich creamy full mouthfeel. Best bottle of this Ive had so far.

I really enjoy this.  This is the first one that Ive had thats not a gusher and it is much better than the others (all of the same 4 pack).  Excellent spiced cake and candied fruit smell with some musty barn in the back.  Flavor is like brown sugar spiked with rum soaked citrus peel with the lack of carbonation in this particular bottle helping me pick up better flavors.  For how rich it is, it finishes very light and refreshing.  Great brew that hits a whole lot of spots.  Thank You Abbaye de Rocs.  2009 12oz.

Bottle - 33cl. A serious, lively beer. You cant open it enough safely to prevent the explosion. Pours hazy, brownish, ruby red color with a long life beige head. Its the same explosion in the aromas. Alcoholic figs, prunes, caramelized malts with a hint of cognac character. Its very sweet and bold, malty in flavors but not overwhelming, very natural and you can feel there is no sugar added actually. Finishes too abruptly, just leaves a
 medium sweet liquorice or molasses feel in the tounge. A bit of alcohol is sensible at the medium. Could be a lot more smooth on the palate with more subtle carbonation. A rich and enjoyable dark-brown ale with some detph but doesnt seem too unique in flavors to me at this time.

Bouteille de 750 ml, au Bières et Bouffe. Arômes fruités (fruits rouges, pruneaux). Robe rousse foncée, beaucoup de particules en suspension, effervescence moyenne. Bien ronde en bouche, la bière montre une belle complexité de malt (caramel, chocolat) et de fortes notes fruitées (fruits rouge, pruneaux). Finale relativement alcoolisée. Rappelle vaguement la Dominus Vobiscum Double de Charlevoix.

Pours a lovely ruby with a thin ring of pure white and no lace. Heavenly aroma - yum yum yum! So sweet - cherries and sherry and everything sweet and wonderful. Vanilla, raisin, cherry, and sweet malt taste - lingering fruitiness. Very tasty! Thin and undercarbonated, but who the hell cares? Fantastic tasting, I could drink this forever. Sweet and fruity and dangerously quaffable.

This dark reddish liquid poors a modest head. Smell is light sour and fruity. The first tastes that come up are caramel, coffee and some other burnt scents together with a tiny bit of berries. Fresh bitters are not very present but just enough. After-taste is mild and a bit one dimensional. A very good beer but the overall palate has room for more complexity.
Aroma of yeast, prunes and toffee. Appearance is red with white head. Flavor is sweet with prunes and raisins. A goof but not very complex beer.

A nose of pears, amaretto and sugars. Taste is of pears, banana, almonds, marzipan and quite a bit of alcohol. A strange brew. Not complex and very unbalanced. A bad bottle? I will rerate if I get the chance.

.33l bottle. Deep ruddy brown with quickly dying large bubbly off-white head. Nose is very sweet and malty. Incredibly explosive, full flavor of sweet malt, dark fruit, prune, molasses, smoke, leather. Very earthy, but with a great effervescence. Reminds of some old style ales ive had in the States, but with a stronger, sweeter body. Terrific!

330 mL bottle from St. Veronus.  Cant believe Ive never tried this one before.  Deep, dark ruby brown with a small beige head.  Malty aroma with some dark fruit and spice.  Lots of anise in the flavour, with some malt, dried fruit and a little smoke.  One of the heavier beers Ive tried, perhaps due to the relatively light carbonation.  All-in-all, a very tasty brew.

watery gusher.  hmm.  at least spew forth with gusto!  Oh well.  Dark chestnut brown, lighter in body than I expected.  Small head.  Some cola nut and Brazil nut aroma.  Blissfully smooth, airy, whipped and gentle.  Surprising.  Sweet, brown sugar, notes of pecan and leather.  Very good beer, little tingly in the deep finish.

Fat malts with heaps of demerara about them.  Light burnt flavours and sweet toffee give way to quite a drying bitterness.  Very long in the finish with the burnt woodiness coming to the fore.  Quite easy drinking but with a great depth and intensity about it.

11.2 oz bottle best b 4 2010 poured lite brown with lots of floaters that rose to the top of this very carbonated brew very lively from the time i cracked the top aromas of fruits,vineger,dough and nalts taste was a sour funk I couldnt finish the bottle it had to be infected so i will have to re rate this one some day soon i hope
I have to say that I dont like dark beer. Ive tried to find something positive about the taste but I simply couldnt.
Wery good aroma with raisin. Large, frothy, off-white head. Good lacing. Mostly diminishing longevity. Clear, brown body. Moderate sweet flavor with notes of raisin. Medium to full palate.
Dark amber colour with frothy beige head. Aroma is alcohol, cellar notes, sirup. Flavor is caramel, slight alc, dark red fruit, plum, lots of candy sugar, sweet dough, slight red apple. Medium body.

Pours chunky amber-brown, with a two finger beige head, very good lasting lacing.  Fantastic aroma, rich and complex malt character, banana bread, sour dough and caramel apple stand out, with undertones of pear, fig, leather and hard-wood.  Medium-full body, zesty, and crisp.  Flavor is full and complex, biscuit, sour apple, cherry, with some grass and earthy notes.  Finishes a touch tart, lightly dry, and mildly bitter.  Well balanced.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2011 Bottle. Dark brown colour with a huge beige head. The aroma of malt, alcohol, liquorice and dried fruits. The flavour is very malty and sweet with some liquorice, dried fruits, spices and slightly bitter with hints of alcohol. Medium to full-bodied.

(bottle) pours a clear ruby colour with a few floaties and a quickly-diminishing off-white head. aroma of dried dark fruits, strawberries, toffee and caramel, with some light notes of alcohol, grain and spice. flavour is roasted malts and yeast, with a hint of dark chocolate, some alcohol and a grainy finish. medium body and carbonation.

Bottle that I won at BCTC.  Pours a cloudy brown with a medium sized beige head.  Big chunky floaty bits in it. Sweet, plum, a little hint of cardboard, and a little bit of candy scented alcohol.  Plum and dark fruit, fruit esters.  Finishes lightly but with some warming alcohol.

Rich brown and opaquish, with a brown head, and substantial lacing.  Aroma is sherry-like, and alcoholic with rich dark fruits and a spicy edge.  Taste is same with bready notes and lingering fruit (with a bit of licorice) into the finish.  Carbonation is vigorous, but not distracting. $10/$750

750ml Bottle. Pours a very dark coppery brown with a little off-white head that doesnt last long. The nose is very light, there are notes of raisins, toffee, a touch of spice and a hint of alcohol. The flavour on the other hand is very big: molasses, dark fruits, honey, lemon, cinnamon and butter all stand out. Full bodied, a bit of carbonation and with a long drying finish, this is a truly outstanding beer.

Bottle. A murky brown pour with large beige head. Lovely complex fruity aroma. Beautifully balanced Belgian beer tasting of dark fruit, caramel, figs, very rich. A quality Belgian beer which I drink whenever I can.

11.2 oz bottle thanks to kryptic, best by some undecipherable date. Pours a dark brown color with a large creamy off-white head- what out this was a bit of a gusher. The aroma is great; Loads of rich fruits, sugars, yeast, loads of complexity. The flavors are excellent; loads of fruity bursting flavors, complex sugars, woodiness, chocolates and tons of awesome richness. The mouthfeel is so creamy it entices me to drink loads of this, if I only had more! Awesome beer. Reminds me of how amazing Belgian beers are.

Bottle, best before 25/09/2011.  The epic commercial description says it all right.  The glorious rating confirms beer afficionnados appreciation for such an amazing beer.  Excellent choice to introduce anyone to the world of high quality classy beers as its amazingly balanced flavors of spicy caramel malts, fruits and subtle hopping should be welcomed by almost anyone.  Won a friendly blind test against Gouden Carolus Classic and Chimay Bleue and Unibroue Trois Pistoles.  Au Québec, Importation privée Bieropholie (une des meilleures bières, rapport qualité/prix: 102$+frais pour 24 bouteilles de 33cl).
Bottle. Cloudy brown pour with light white head. This beer is very nice. Flavor and aroma is dark malts, fruit flavor from esters, slightly sweet, and spices. This beer finishes nice.

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of yeast, cola, slight dark ripe fruits, slight black cherry, and a hint of caramel.  Smells a bit like black cherry soda.  Poured brown in color with a large, fizzy, tan head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Full of small, medium, and large particles throughout.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and slightly bitter.  Tastes of malts, dark ripe fruits, slight cocoa, slight herbs, cola, yeast, and a hint of caramel.  Medium body.  Lightly sticky texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, herb, yeast finish is lightly dry.

750 mL into tulips (shared). Pours a clear deep brown with ruby accents (extremely hazy, muddy brown once the yeast is tossed in) with a two-finger tan head that has okay retention and no lacing. Aroma is rum soaked cherries, milk chocolate, brown sugar, some spicy alcohol. Taste is not too sweet like the other Abbaye des Rocs offerings. Very balanced with cloves, nutmeg, caramel, candi sugar, rum-raisin, wheat bready malt. Not too much bittering hops. Pretty refreshing actually. Fairly creamy palate. 9% is completely hidden.

Reddish brown pour. Aroma of strong malt and yeast, a bit of fruit. Carmel, toffee, Flavor is fruity and earthy, a bit dirty. Some leather and chocolate. Finish is chalky and long. Big, rich palate. Nice beer.

Dark orange in color with a quickly vanishing head. The aroma is strong, malty and sweet. The taste is overwhelming - I thought I had opened a Brune, but this is more like a barley wine! The taste is dominated by (too much) sweetness, malt and some citrus notes. The palate is rich. Overall an interesting beer with a balance I do not fancy.
Bottle @ Barley Wine. Brown with tan head. Sweet alcoholic aroma with fruit and candysugar. Taste sweet figs chocolate plum malt alcohol.

This copper ale poured with a decent beige head and a candi sugar aroma. The flavor is rich roasted malt with a chalky dry finish and some carbonation. Its neither sweet nor sour and is actually a little bitter. Not what I expected, yet is is a very good brew.

A brown beer with a nice head.Aroma is fruity, leathery, & slightly spicy. Taste is fruit(peach), dash of chocolate that leaves a nice lacing. The 9% ABV is amazingly well hidden, in fact I didnt taste alcohol. The smoothest Belgian I have had.

Bottle 33cl.
Pours a murky brown colour with normal size head and good carbonation.
Aroma is very attractive and smells like caramel, fruits and raisins.
Taste is also caramel and very sweet.
Aftertaste hardly has any alcohol, but is great and warm going down.
Brown with a lively beige foam. Sweet and complex with notes of caramell, sugar, estery fruits and sweet sweet raisins. Rather vinous, rather complex but a tad too sweet for me most of the time.
Big bottle from Pelgrims, Aarschot. Aroma is of caramel and wood. Taste is also caramelly with a sweet undertone, more like grapes I would say. Very very very fine beer.

33cl bottle. Pours an opaque brown colour with a creamy beige head. Aroma of brown sugar, caramel, resin and  dark chocolate. Taste is quite sweet with cramel, dark fruits and a hint of raisin. Full bodied; a bit winey. Great beer.

750ml bottle. Best by 2010. Sweeter aroma. Juicy citrus fruits. A bit of basement must. Brown sugar. Freshly baked wheat bread. Lightly toasted nuts. The bread and nut aromas increase substantially as the beer opens up. Pours a glowing dark orange with a thin ring of a white head. Flavor is rather sweet. Lots and lots of nectarine, plum and pear flavors. Slightly vinous character. Very little hops showing in this one. Toasty and bready with mild fruit notes. Leaning toward full bodied. Creamy texture. Average carbonation with a pleasant sweeter malty finish. Not mindblowing by any stretch, but a tasty Belgian Strong, lacking any flaws but perhaps showing its age. Thanks James!

Pour a rich, opaque brown with brown head. Aroma is complex, very malty with plum and over-ripe fruit notes. Taste is similar, with some detectable roasted and chocolate character from the dark malts that really adds to the complexity of the beer. Slightly overly sweet for my palate, a little more bitterness could have helped the balance. Still very enjoyable.

Enjoyed on tap in a whiskey snifter.  The sample pours a deep brown color, with a nice white head that lasts several minutes.  The nose is one that is perhaps the best Ive experienced since sampling beers of such ilk as St. Bernardus Abt 12.  Caramel, German chocolate, and malty sweetness.  The palate shows evidence that this beer goes through a long aging process, showing a malty beginning and center, followed by a slightly estery finish that is just a bit dry.  Overall, an excellent Belgian Strong Dark.

Pours a dark brown colour with a cream coloured head. Hops can be seen floating in the beer. Aroma of dark fruits, brown sugar, candied sugar, caramel, and molasses. Flavour is the same as the aroma. Has a vinous quality. Reminiscent of the the Trappístes Rochefort but not as good.

Big bottle, Pours nice with a reddish brown color. Aroma is sweet but not over powering or memerable. Small cream white head is a nice addition to the beer appearance. Taste is pleasant with fruit flavors, soom sweetness like molasses and caramel. Malt comes through nicely with some spiciness from the hops. All in all a very nice Belgian strong.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2010 Sweet and a bit "winey" fruitness as described.  A bit of an orangey, malty sweet aromatic spiciness in the nose.  Brown-orange color with a tan head.  Smoothe and complex with a bit of alcohol taste in there to warm you up.

Bottled 33cl from crackedkettle.com. It pours a murky reddish dark brown beer with a beautiful, nicely lasting rich creamy light beige head. Coconut, candy sugar, molasses, blue cheese, aniseed, vanilla, hops, mango, pear, pumpernickel, plums and apricot showing up in the nose which is remarkably strong, mindblowingly pleasant and just simply fantastic! Sweet complex taste. Full bodied with a lot of candy sugar and caramel appearing with tropical fruits (which include coconut and mango) accompanying the sweet components. Extremely pleasant. Lively carbonation. Good lacework. Residual sugars in the finish which is mostly fruity and powerful, lingering for quite a while. Marvellous!
33 cl Bottle. Reddish brown color with a huge brown head. Very complex aroma and similar flavors of chocolate, ripe fruit, caramel, brown sugar, spices and more. Simply great !
Bottle. Poured a deep brown,nose was clearly malty, with dark  fruit. Deep and complex flavors, with a hint of sweetness.Smooth, drinkable, with hints of spice. Excellent.

Poured with all sorts of chunky floaties, but smelled and tasted absolutely phenomenal.  Just a beautiful nutty sweetness to it thats hard to pin down precisely but a new favorite for me.  Im gonna have to drink this one more often, worth the effort to decant, and great even if a little chewy.
Lovely beer. Pours hazy dark brown with thick tan head. Lots of toffee sweetness, dark fruits  and spicy notes. I like the yeasty chunks that add to the flavour.

Another nice offering from pfoxyjohn: Poured a bright cloudy mahogany colour again, and something noticeably different is its not quite as sweet as the previous beer. Raisiny, caramel and noticeable alcohol on the palate. Aroma is very fine with some yeastiness.
Bottle. Nice red-brown color. Fruity, buttery, yeasty, choclaty. Sweet. Nice hop touch.

750 ml bottle.
Pours hazy brown-orange.
Very yeasty aroma.
Fruity belgian taste. 
Gets better when it gets closer to room temperature.

Bottle with great thanks to HogTownHarry, I think this bottle is 4 years old. Appearance: Wow, almost like jello due to the amount of suspended solids - some the size of cornflakes. Small dirty white head, orange brown body. Aroma: Pine, grapes, orange, yeast and malt, quite a sharp aroma. Flavour: Initially quite malty and then orange/pine/citrus with earth tones and banana, quite a lot going on. The mouthfeel is odd due to the amount of yeast particles. Very nice.
pours hazy mahogany with a tan head.  matly sweet with some notes of dark fruit,  caramel, and wood.  Tasty

Pours a slightly hazed mahogany with a tall creamy tan head that quickly fades to a skim and holds. Aroma is lots of wood, grape and earth notes before I even got close to the glass. Getting a little closer... caramel, fresh figs, plums, overripe red apple, wet soil, musty orange, spice, banana nut bread and hints of balsamic vinegar. Flavor is toasted wood, toasted grain, rich caramel, coffee, chocolate, earth, nutty toffee, wet leaves, banana bread, lots of fresh and dried dark fruits and burnt sugar. Finish is full of earth and wood notes, with plenty of burnt sugar and dark fruit just a hint of roast bitterness. Palate is lighter than the aroma would tell with a perfect effervescence and a nice dry feel throughout. Fantastic brew, rich aroma and flavor with a playfully light palate and well hidden high abv.... really great.

Sampled from a 750 ml green bottle this beer poured a dark orange-brown color with a large tan head. The aroma was tart apple and sugar. The flavor was tart, tangy and bitter with notes of apple and caramel and a hint of vinegar. The finish was medium length tart apple vinegar.  Ok.

Sleeper bargain at Only Café in beautiful Greektown, Toronto. Nice lightly cloudy chestnut pour with tan foamy head, releasing a nose of fruity acidity and sweetness. Taste rich toffee-like malts, that beautiful tangy dark fruit, banana pie-spice and cola. Some demerera under the long, great lightly acidic finish. Extremely consistent impression from first whiff to last gulp, a real winner.

Dark, deep brown, almost black in appearance. Quite unsettled, despite a lot of standing time. Heavy, ripe fruit evident, particularly cherry and blackberry and quite vineous. Strong alcoholic flavour, sweet, but balanced enough to not be overpowering.
Gusher with many floaties.  I am not a huge fan of the floaties.  However, aroma of fruits, sugar and bread.  Fruity taste with acidic aftertaste.  Not bad.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2009 750 mL bottle courtesy of StlWill. This was on my wantlist forever. Thanks! Best by 14/02/2011. Valentines day... how sweet! Pours a dark reddish brown color. Cloudy with huge floaties. Large frothy head with good head retention and some lacing, though the glass seems to be coating more by floatie sludge than last. Aroma of earthy malts, chocolate, brown sugar, bread, crayons, light fruit notes including cherry and apple. Taste is decidedly more fruity with definite notes of cherry, berries, apple, apricot. Also brown sugar, yeast, toffee, spice and almost sherrylike notes. Full bodied. The floaties definitely make their presence known on the palate. Very soft carbonation. All in all a very nice beer. 8/3/9/3/16
750 mL bottle at the Relentless Thirst Gathering in Richmond, VA, 8.29.09.  2005 vintage I think. Pours reddish copper with a medium head. Perpetual head retention and nice lacing. Aroma of slight funk, berries, cherries and raisins. Taste is caramel, other malty notes and light berry notes. Medium bodied. 8/4/9/4/17

[1856-20081112] 330mL bottle. Fruity heavy yeast aroma with heavy toasted perfume. Hazy, dark red amber body with no head and ridiculously huge chunky floaties. Heavy fruity yeast continues in the flavour again with heavy perfume. Medium body. Quite fruity.
(w/ DuctTape, jerc)
pungent melted caramel and brown sugar. taste is sweet, but balanced. aroma kept its teeth through the whole glass. very impressive.

Colore rosso-arancione vivace ma un pò torbido,schiuma scarsa,sottile ma persistente.Aroma di malto,miele e richiami di vino.Sapore ancora di miele,cioccolato,discretamente alcoolica ma in modo piacevole.Una gran birra!
Un sentito ringraziamento ad un amico patito di ciclismo per avermela portata direttamente dal Belgio,anche se so che in città ci devessere un pub che la tiene.

750 mL bottle.  Dark brown-reddish pour with a nice tan head.  Aroma of barnyard, Belgian yeast, malt and plums.  Great taste of yeast, malts, dark fruits and caramel.  Fantastic, slight alcohol finish.

Bottle.  Pours a gorgeous deep red with a quickly-dissipating tan head that left minor lacing on the glass.  Aroma is more subtle than i anticipated, but i did get malt, candi sugar, and dark fruit.  Taste, however, is an explosion, with malt up front dissolving into dark fruits such as plum, date, raisin, and lighter fruit like green apple.  Finishes smooth and sweet.  I really tasted the FARM on this one, too; the grain came out at just the right times.  Alcohol barely noticeable.  Its delicious.

750ml bottle.  Labeled "Brasserie des Rocs".  Best before 2009.  Sampled 3-28-09.

Been wanting to try this one for a while and its certainly a wonderful Belgian strong ale.

Pours a light murky brown with TONS of chunks & floaties....not just at the bottom of the bottle...right from the very first pour.  More than Ive ever seen before.  Small tan head that dissipates to virtually no head and doesnt leave much lacing.

Malty, sweet, and very fruity.  Runs the gamut on fruit flavors from sip to sip.  The standard dark fruits such as raisins and figs, with notes of tangerine, banana, grapes, and apples.  Absolutely delicious!

Alcohol is undetectable in the taste.  Mouthfeel is wonderful...creamy but not syrupy with a nice finish.

Deserves its place right up there with other top-tier Belgian ales!

750mL bottle poured into a snifter, after getting this gusher under control.

Pours a slightly murky reddish brown that shows amber when held up to the light.  There are plenty of floaties in there and the head is large and lingers for quite a while, leaving a little bit of lacing.

The aroma is big with tons of sweet dark malts and lots of dark fruits, especially raisins and figs.  There seems to be a molasses sweetness as well.  There is a bit of an alcohol burn in the nose as well.

The taste was great, much like the aroma.  Tastes like raisins soaked in a highly sugary alcohol.  The malt base is still dominant throughout and though I mention the sweetness, its definitely not overpowering as in some versions of the style.

The mouthfeel is velvety smooth with plenty of carbonation.

This is a nice example of a Belgian brown, one of the better Ive had recently.  I definitely feel lucky to be able to walk into my local shop and pick this up whenever I want.  Good stuff.

Pours red/brown with a substantial but quickly dispersing tan coloured head. Nose  is quite vinous, red and dark fruits in abundance, supported well by sweet caramel & toffee malt. Palate translates well, with the fruit a little more reserved than on the nose. Sweet malt dominates with an almost woody, nutty character evident, probably from the yeast. Finish is rather long and faintly sweet.
bottle, light brown colour, very nice white head, hoppy, alcohol taste a bit dominating,a bit sweet, dark fruit, very nice beer!!
Have had this multiple times, one of my favorites. Mild spice, yeasty, dark fruits and just a hint of sweetness. Went very well with a filet mignon

Bottle.  Pours a clear redish brown, with some floaties and  a small white head.  Aroma of dark fruit, spice, yeast, malt.  Taste is sweet dark fruit, malt, spice, sugar, yeast, and light warming alcohol.  Mouth is lively and smooth.  Very enjoyable.  Overall, a nice belgian ale.

Date: 27/2/09
Beer info: Bottled in green 750ml bottle 9.0% abv BB 2011?

Sampling notes:
Served lightly chilled in chalice.
Plenty of yeasty chunks floating in a deep bronze body, capped with an offwhite foam that is thick and likes to hang around.
Vinous aromatics, dark fruits and berries, earthy spice, hint of raisin and liquorice, maybe even a touch of bitter orange. Some malt in background, fortifying the nose, dark brown sugar, light roastiness, possibly a touch of grainy wheat.
Lucious malt body, smooth, chewy syrup consistancy, huge length, low carbonation, somewhat balanced by a drying alcohol/wheat-like sensation.
Big malt body gets the ball rolling, milk chocolate, brown sugar, nuts, then hit with raisins and blackberry fruits...would make a tasty chocolate bar. Palate continues with spice, tobacco leafiness, more dried fruit (date?), which linger on a moderately bitter, slightly drying without being boozy, finish.
Funnily enough I had memories of two other beers whilst drinking this...the original Belgian chocolate ale we brewed, and a Chimay Bleu of a few years cellaring...the latter seems a good way of putting it. Really well rounded, and lengthy palate, but after trying three of this style in a reasonably short space of time its easy to be choosy, and this fantastic ale is the lesser of the Rochefort 8 and St Bernardus 12...by only the slightest of margins!

Brown pour with tan head and lace. Hard brown sugar and roasted malt on the nose. Same hard brown sugar, a hint of dried fruit with no bitter. Medium full bodied beer with very good carbonation. Very nice offering.
Pours a murky brown with orange hues.  White head. Fruit and alcohol in the aroma dominated by yeast. Strong vinous flavors and some alcohol, sweet malts with some dark fruits.

Bottle @ Delirium. Clear amber to brown beer with a medium sized, creamy and blond beige head. The aroma is very malty. Like Finnish traditional easter food "mämmi" or syrupy sweet bread, and it has prunes, dates and raisins. Some brown sugar and light spiciness too. The finish is lightly hopped and herbal, a hint of alcohol is present. The flavor is complex and malty, dark fruity and overall sweetish. Slightly bitter in the finish and the alcohol is well hidden. The palate is full bodied, very smooth and syrupy. Lovely.

Niiice. Caramel brown body with many particles, tan head fades to lacing. Sweet candied sugar nose, caramel toffe, and a touch of dark fruits. Taste was full of raisin and fig, caramel, some apple - the hop and malt balanced very well. Medium, almost syrupy, palate soft and fizzy. Delicious brew!
Crushed with Jakebra.  Not much nose, but what is there is nice.  Flavor is subtle but awesome.  Sour, musty, smooth, dark fruits and plenty of awesomeness.  Dug it.
Dark reddish colour with small off-beige head.Aroma is strong fruity with full strong body,warming sweet mouth feels and well balanced smooth finish.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy amber color with a medium sized off white head and quite a lot of sediment throughout.  The aroma is sweet, fruity (I get darker fruits), and caramel malt.  The flavor blends the fruit and malt together nicely.  Moderately sweet caramel malt with dark fruits and spices.  Very little bitterness or alcohol here.  Medium-full bodied; I was content to sip this slowly from my tulip glass and enjoy.

Pours a reddish brown with a good amount of sediment.  Its aromas are sweet and has dark fruits feel.  The flavors are very strong and of strong malts and some caramel and dark fruits are present.  Full of stong flavors, a very pleasant dark beer.

bottle poured into a trappist glass has a muddy brown red color with little head on the beer and carbonation pooling up through the center of the beer. aroma has rich dark fruit, caramel, musty yeast, and some sweetness. mouth feel is medium and the carbonation is plenty. flavor has lots of malted body, plumb, raisin, prune, and yeasty spice. certainly a big brown.

Bottle. Pours a hazy brown with sediment. The aroma is apple, malt, and some caramel & dark fruit. The flavor is a bit stronger than I would have preferred. At first, you can taste the fruit (apple, dark fruits) in the mouth - but it ends with alcohol and malt.

Bottle. I agree very much with the ratings. A very nice beer. Dark brown with huge pale brown head, not quite clear as there are some sediments. Aroma of prunes, dates and dark fruits. Taste sweet, prunes and dates and a little hopp bitterness in the sweet finish

Bottle from Kris or Nelson Wines, its been too long to remember now. Pours reddish amber with a lasting off white head and lots of sediment. Nose is sweet malts with dried fruit, caramel and candi sugar. Taste is much the same, obvious Belgian yeast notes, a little cakey with some subtle warmth. Hadnt had a Belgian brune for a while and it definitely hit the spot, its kinda given me the thirst for them again.

Bottle: Ruddy brown, smaller creamy beige head, lots of UFOs detectable; solid sweet caramelly nose with a distinctive touch of coriander and with some vinous illusions; moderate to solid sweet flavour, medium bodied; warming alcohol in the sweet-caramelly finish. Pretty overrated sweety............

Bit of a gusher. 33cl bottle, gift from donfardz64.
Slightly funky, yeasty aroma. Quite a floral nose, mostly rose. Sweet, biscuity malt aromas, vanilla and a candy-like sweetness.
Flavours arent as sweet as the aromas. Theres a bit of a zesty, almost citrus tang to begin with. This then turns a bit bitter near the end.
Plum and banana fruits on a strong, grainy malt base.

Bottle. Ruby-brown body with some dregs that probably isnt suppose to be there. Big very shortlived head. Aroma is prunes, sugar candy and some caramel. Flavor is very sweet and malty with notes of burnt sugar and caramel. It unfortunately seems a bit flat, but is a nice brew anyway. Hopefully the next one will be better, with a higher carbonation and without dregs.

Bottle.  Protein and yeast really shaken out, ruby-copper body is ((illegible)), luscious creamy lasting beige head.  Sweet malty alcohol nose, some mineral water, caramel and earth with seemingly subtle candi sugar (though I later discover this is a product of pure malt).  Taste is a sweet caramel base, a tad too much alcohol showing, muddled fruit and faint figs, but a unified presentation.  Has some light port wine character and amusement park flair.  Full but not obese body, hops are totally faded, smooth and enjoyable all the way through.  Very classy, though Idve loved (and will undoubtedly love in the future) a fresher example.  This brewery can do no wrong by me.

Dégusté avec french tickler le 16 avril 2007.
Cloudy dark amber poor with lots of sediments and a THICK light brown foamy head. Aromas of burbon vanilla, french toast, brown sugar, alcohol, caramel, cinnamon and apple/pear. Very evolutive aromas. Aromas also remind me of a typical rochefort yeast. Very Creamy, thick body, extremely well balanced. Perfect bitterness, nothing extreme... Perfect effervescence! Very complexe flavors added a hint of candy sugar and prunes. 1 -> Creamy 2 -> Oily 3-> Dry bitter finish. Exceptional beer!
33cl bottle from hopduvel @ Gent Very complex flavours strong after taste fruity tastes heavier than it is.

33cl bottle from ølbutikken. Best before date was not readable.
pours coudy caramelly brown, offwhite head.
aroma is slightly sour/citrussy(lime), cellary, soap, fruits.
flavor was sour, fruity, berries, slight cellary. quite well balanced. sawdust??, caramel, alc well hidden.
overall too sour and fruity for my taste, but i could sense a beer well crafted.

750 ml bottle with a best by date of 2010 poured into a chalice produced a small brown head that turned to a light lace. Wow this is the first bottle I have got from this brewery that wasnt a gusher or had floaties. The body of this brew was clear reddish brown in color.

The initial whiff I got seemed a bit sour. Then malts are huge on this bottle, very much overpowering all the other aromas. The flavor is very sweet lots of candy sugar and caramel. This brew had a medium mouth to it with light carbonation exactly what I would expect from a Belgian brown. 

Easy to drink I was kind of confused not seeing any floaties in this bottle I will have to revisit this brew some time, not as good as the grand cru from them
Bottle at the Derby Winter Beer Festival. Very fruity and slightly spicy, this has flavours of dried fruits and burnt sugar with a typically Belgian yeasty quality.
