750ml bottle. Pours a slightly hazy amber with a lot of yeast chunks and a good sized off white head that lasts leaving some lacing. Aroma of cherries, dark fruit, light caramel, and yeast. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium full mouthfeel with alot of yeast chunks floating in my mouth. The beer tastes great but the amount of yeast in the bottle is crazy and makes it slightly difficult to drink.

Bottle. Dark liquor, alcoholic, sour, sugar beet molasses. A small off-white head. fully dimishing. The body is nearly black. It starts moderate bitter and finishes a little bit sweeter, average duration. The body is medium, the texture is kind of syrup. Flat carbonation with a moderate alcoholic finish.
lots of carbination, thick creamy head with light lacing.  Pours dark yellow with the aroma of hops & malts.  nice balance and the price is always right!  lots of floaters

Volcanic gusher of foam from the bottle that would certainly impress my 3-yr old son.  I think I lost 1/3 of the bottle to my mother in laws tablecloth.  After pouring into glass, small wisps of foam coat the surface and provide subtle lacing.  Nice deep amber color.  Smell of malt and little hops.  Smooth mellow texture and flavor.  Very nice and well rounded. The slightest amount of good buttery sourness on the back sides of my tongue.  Brown sugar sweetness and slight alchohol nose round off the finish.  Excellent beer.  Now I must go squeeze the remaining 1/3 glass out of the table cloth.
12oz bottle bought at the great Tanakaya liquor store in Tokyo for around $4.

Bottle. Damn, there is a lot of yeast in this. Well its a pours a muddy dark brown with a thin staying white film head. Aroma has plums, liqourice, chocolate and a vinious edge to it. Flavour is very dark. There are plums, raisins, dark chocolate and quite a touch of hoppy bitterness. A slighty vinious streak runs through it. It is a good beer, sadly it is a bit let down by the large amount of particles in the beer. My girlfriends glass was better poured (relax, I poured that too). Still there is a lot of residue... but a stunningly nice beer otherwise.

Nice rich claret colour with a large off white head. Rich plums, grapes and vinious aroma with dark malt and spice. Rich plummy, dark fruits, chocolate, roasted malts with hints of coriander and hops. A rich sweet fruity beer which hides alcohol stength well. A hearty mouthfeel with a chewy character probably due to mature yeast particles floating in my bottle. As Pat says your not a real man if u dont drink yeast. Lol but i aint no man

500th Beer; thanks to golubj, kleyland and KieferUGA for help in procuring me beers from their respective areas and the spreading of liquid culture.  Bottle; poured a murky brown, with some orange coloring.  Aroma dark fruit, grape, brown sugar; sweet and yeasty.  Some spice.  Taste is complex and sweet; flavors seemed to come in waves.  Malt backbone; with splashes of citrus/orange, sugar/brown sugar, spice, and some grape/wine.  Alcohol well hidden.  Chocolate hints as well.  Fitting beer for the occasion, because I really enjoyed it

Bottle:  Poured a murky amber/brown with a large beige head.  Lots of particles suspended below the surface.  Nose is citrus and sweet, some winelike tones, even some hops.  Taste is rich with sweetness; some wine, fruitiness, citrus, and malt.  Some detection of the alcohol presence.  Interesting, but not quite what Id hoped for.

A super hazy brown ale with a thick light moka head, lots of kleenex floaties. A very pleasant sweet candy sugar aroma, yeast, oranges, caramel and spices. In mouth, wow! A delicious beer with sweet burned caramel, light moka, and good hops, followed by spiced yeast, licorice, and citrus. Rich and onctuous, this is a good sipping beer. Went well with the Cordobes. Bieropholie Private import.
Hazy ruby/copper color. Lasting tannisth frothy head. Aroma full of fruit, citrus, and a hint of chocolate. Complex taste. Chocolate, some cherries maybe? Definitely some caramel as well.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2007 Bottle. Pours a brownish red with a tall tan head with many floating yeast particles apparent. There is a very doughy, bready nose with hints of sourdough, citrus, banana, and dark spices. There is rich bread throughout the flavor with hints of chocolate and spices. The finish reminds me of a molasses cookie with bread, bananas, and citrus fruit. The biggest turn off here is that I can actually feel the giant yeast particles hitting my lips and teeth when I drink. Its like pulp and I want to chew it, which is weird. This was from the first modest pour out of the bottle too. Not my favorite Belgian style, but this is a darn good take on it.
Bottle. Pours a hazy dark amber color with a longlasting off-white head. Sweet malty dark fruit aroma. Sweet malty caramel flavor with hints f dark fruit. Sweet malty warming finish.
Great aroma.  Palate is rather dry.  I am slightly surprised with the lack of sugar, because there is some definite sweetness going on.

750ml bottle via trade with JayG.  So many thanks, thought this beer would elude me forever, yet 649 people before me were not so eluded.  Pours gushing, not terrible, but a little over excited from a big bruiser of a 750.  Pours cloudy pale orange with a thin half finger than head.  The nose is quite light, and slightly sweet.  The taste is intriguing and complex and not so strong.  Lots of different fruit flavors not rainbow stripe gum, but complex.  Very light, lets see how it progresses...

Bottle @ Brugse Beertje, Brugge.       Pours hazy reddish/brown with a beautiful, everlasting  tan head. Dry, malty and caramellish aroma. Also scents of dried dark fruits, alcohol and yeast. Taste is moderately sweet and very complex. A strong malt base with layers of fruit flavors; plums, grapes, raisins and  tropical. Also some fruity acidiy hand in hand with candy-sugar... Mild and gentle hopbitterness. Medium to full body. Long flavorfull finish. A wonderful beer.
0,33 bottle at Beer Mania, Brussels. Amber dark. Really smooth, nice mixture of tastes. Well hidden alcohol.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2007 pours amber with chunks of yeast floating throughout.  aroma is tart with yeast and spice notes.  there is also sweet malt notes in the form dark fruit vapors.  taste is more subtle than the aroma. it is tangy and sweet with the usual fruit and yeast notes but is unusually well formed.  finish is tart and dry.  well carbonated and very drinkable.

RB rating 400. 33 cL bottle. Pours orange brown with a good off-white head. Aroma of malts, yeast, slight citric and fruity. Flavour is sweet and spicy. Soft malt flavour mixes with the alcohol giving a strong and fullbodied flavour and finish.
Bottle but tasted it also on draft. One of my favorite beers. Very complex beer. Although 9% alcohol, the taste is very balanced a little sweet and enough bitter. A perfect beer

Bottle.  Aroma of sweet malt, dark fruit, yeast, and citrus.  The mouthfeel is very wine-like, but with a little carbonation.  The flavor is a compilation of all the aforementioned smells, maybe some brown sugar also.  Pretty intense initial flavor and nice finish.

Best before end 2007, 750mL bottle.  I have no idea how I havent rated this yet.  Pours a clear brownish red with a bunch of protein/yeasty floaties with a three finger beige head, very good retention.  Aroma of brown and powdered sugar, yeast, ripe apples, lemon rinds, raisins, and maybe some nutmeg.  The flavor was pretty much what I was expecting with a bit more goodness.  Some chocolate, spicy alcohol in a good way, stronger caramel, though the lemon seems to switch to a mix between orange hard candy and orange rinds.  Overall fairly sweet, but has a dry finish.  Highly carbonated, medium bodied.  I think this is very good, though rated a tad too high.  As I typed that, I realized that it acually is about as good as what its overall rated.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Pours an orangish hue massive chunks if protein and yeast. We actually filtered part of the bottle and a lot of the aroma was taken out. Aroma was sweet maltiness with some spices coming through. Flavor had notes of some apple and maybe some sweettarts. Pretty unique flavor but this just didnt seem like it should be this high.

Bottle shared by bdburdman. Pours a dirty orange with lots of chunky sediment. Aroma was spicey: lemon, light caramel malt, yeast, perhaps a bit of cinnamon. Flavors of yeast, lemon and pale malt. Sweet and medium bodied with a dry...chunky finish.
Bottle: Pours a deep copper with lots of floaties, white head. Aroma, raisins, yeasts, fruits, and some spices. Flavor,, spices, yeasts, caramel malts. Pretty solid.

Pours a hazy, bubbly, chunky, burnt orange with a thick, well retained light tan head.  Wonderful aromas of plum, apple, other citrus, some malts, and a touch of some caramel.  Taste is quite full flavored.  Pretty sweet, a lot of caramel and plum in the taste.  Really smooth, and quite easy drinking, even though it is chunky as hell, but thats to be expected as all Des Rocs beers Ive had have been like this.  Great mouthfeel, kind of danced on the tastebuds.  Great brew from a great abbey.  Thumbs up.

750ml bottle, with no best by date. This one was a bit of a gusher. Thankfully I opened it near the sink, and only lost a few ounces.

Pours a dark caramel brown with a frothy two finger head, with only an eight ounce pour. The foam takes forever to fall to a thick cap, leaving behind a thick sheeting of lace.

Smell; chalky yeast up front, and then becomes fruity with figs, dates and plums. Brown sugar, caramel and bread dough give this a very nice malty aroma.

Taste; theres lots of dark fruits in here with the figs, dates and plums, but theres something else in there I cant quite place. Some cloves and spices fill out the middle, and then tone of sweet caramel and brown sugar malts come out. The finish is a bit chalky from the yeast, and the alcohol has a definite presence as well.

Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with a nice smooth natural carbonation. The drinkability is really good, and the only real complaint I have is that it is a touch sweeter than I would have liked. Overall this is a reall damn good beer.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Fiery red pour thick with sediment.  Zinfandel aroma fills the air with the pop of the cap.  Dense, rich dark fruits, cranberry orange scone follow.  Lollipop sweetness.  More red wine in the flavor.  Rich toffee malts and a bright clementine sunshine in the finish.  Lacking the tannic dryness I was hoping for here, with a slightly watery, flattened mouthfeeling in general.  It has the density of port but fails to contextualize this - small complaints, really.  A fine aperterif.

Bottle at Delirium Cafe, Brussels.  Pours an attractive hazy brown with a smallish, dense white head.  Aroma tickles the nostrils with dark pit fruits, berries, cherries, and a candied sweetness. Wow. The first scent of this is absolutely divine and comes from nowhere - really amazing; vibrant and complex to no end.  Taste is really interesting but not as good, say, as the aroma.  Strong alcohol  and warming presence throughout.  Interesting sweet-sour duo, with fruity ester sweetness and a lingering spice.  Quite sweet in the finish, with a lingering, rasping slightly bitter after.  Nice, creamy palate. Excellent, falls a bit short with a muddled, alcoholic taste.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2014 Bottled 75cl at Delirium Cafe, Brussels. Pours redish brown with a tall beige head. Aroma is complex, sweet and fruity. Notes of caramel and chocolate. Taste is also complex. Sweet, fruity, caramel. A bit of hops to balance everything. Warming alcohol in the end.

750 Bottle.  Tulip glass.  I tried to uncap the bottle in a very slow and gentle manner.  However, the foam still erupted.  I had to stop and wait but became impatient and decided to just pour it.  That being said it poured a dark brown with a red tinge, tons of sediment floating all around, and a head that was still moderately thick.  Aroma is dominated by fruit and malt.  Flavor is of raisin, plum, prune, caramel and sugar.  Sweet and malty.  The sediment makes for an interesting palate.  Mild finish.  Alcohol is well hidden.

Cloudy dark amber poor with lots of sediments and a THICK light brown foamy head. Aromas of burbon vanilla, french toast, brown sugar, alcohol, caramel, cinnamon and apple/pear.  Very evolutive aromas.  Aromas also remind me of a typical rochefort yeast. Very Creamy, thick body, extremely well balanced.  Perfect bitterness, nothing extreme... Perfect effervescence!  Very complexe flavors added a hint of candy sugar and prunes.  1 -> Creamy 2 -> Oily 3-> Dry bitter finish.  Exceptional beer!
750ml - Light, light brown head of substantial size, toffee colored liquid, very small and fine bubbles.  Candy sweet astringency fading to a woody finish.  I liked it more as time passed.  OK.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2007 Poured a light brown color with a thinnish white head.  Big hunks of matter are plentiful in the beer, which these brews are well known for.  When swirled, it looks like a snow globe in a world of beer - dare to dream.  Aroma of Belgian malts, light plum and wood, graham cracker.  Exceptionally light and smooth palate.  The taste has a vinous dry sweetness to it, and the finish is slightly oaky and a bit sour, which lingers and leaves the suggestion of taking another sip.  Its subtle but not simple, and dangerously drinkable for a 9%.
Pours a hazy brown color with a off white head.  Aroma is malty, woody, and slightly sour.  Flavor is malty, slightly woody, with some sour notes.

(Bottle @ Delerium cafe, Brussels, Belgium):  Pours a lightish brown-red color, good head, diminishing, good lacing, off-white.  Grapejuice aroma, sweet, some hops.  Not like a belgian I had before.  Sweet taste, not as floral, a little skunky to start, good moutheel.  Interesting, maybe aged?

Verre de dégustation, provenant dune bouteille verte de 750 ml, lors dune soirée chez Glouglouburp. Arôme: Odeur de petits fruits et dépices. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée avec de la lie. Présence dun moyen col crémeux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de prunes, de raisins et de caramel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. (Rating #952)

Bottle gift from stegosaurus. Red/brown pour with huge head. Nose of fruit and alcohol. Taste was fruit with a hint of brown sugar and spice. Not a bad brew but very very odd tasting. I enjoyed this very much.
Pours brown with a moderate head. Bottle boiled over, which sucked. The beer has a fair hop aroma with undertones of fruit and caramel. Strong caramel and hop flavor with bits of fruit and spice.

bottle . . pours cloudy amber with a fizzy light tan head . . aroma is sweet, dried fruit, hops, orange peel, spices . . it makes me want to dive in . . tastes begins sweet to the tongue with nice carbonation . . slightly bitter, alcohol flavor . . full and malty . . its creamy and very complex . . spices . . nice beer! . . slightly bitter though . .

Bottle, very lively, pours to a cloudy burnished amber with a foamy off-white head. Difficult to not get sediment in the glass. A strong spiced aroma, with orange zest and hop resins. A full, but fizzed, mouthfeel. A strong sweet malty flavour with an over-arching zesty hoppiness cleasing the palate. OK for me, but there are better in this style.

Another perfection of belgium art work. Great beer with a magnificent flavour, sweet and hard bodied nice with a good cigar. Do not waste your glass with bad this great beer need a good cigar. One of the best of my life. Thanx again to my great friend Oguz Can.
UPDATED: JAN 27, 2008 A very complex aroma of wood, wine, ripe red fruit. The beer has a certain thickness and a very complex flavour.

Bottle. 1 Pint 9.4 FL. OZ.  Great looking beer.  Cloudy reddish-brown with many large particles floating throughout with a nice creamy head.  Sweet, fruity aroma is simply mouth watering.  Exceptionally smooth palate. Flavor did not let me down. Impressive.

Bottle, head starts seeping out before I even pour it, despite safe storage. Lots of floaties. I questioned that this bottle might be infected due to the enormous head, but all the elements of the aroma seemed to be OK. Anyway, some fruitiness, and sweet malts, wine like notes, and a bit of sharp tartiness. The flavor is very carbonated, with a bit of fruit, yeast, a touch of caramel and spice. The carbonation level is really out of hand, and its hard to enjoy all the flavors while it keeps prickling at my tongue.
Bottle. Nice tan head with good duration. Color is dark amber with lots of sediments. Aroma is quite powerful with lots of spices and fruits. Taste is nice and complex with spices and fruits as well.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2008 750ml, not a gusher or full of sediment. pours muddy brown with hints of red with small tan head. nose is very red winey, dates, bread, and yeast. flavor is also pretty bland, some plums, grapes, and caramel. carbination is a tad prickly. alcohol is very well hidden. abbaye des rocs beers are just boring, overrated, and inconsistent..3.5.

11/20/07, 750ml 2005 bottle. i couldnt say this improved much with age but it didnt get worse. this is a really subtle, winey BSA. the palate is short. it is really nothing special and highly over rated but the wine quality is nice. too bad most of the bottles pour huge chunks of sediment. that really hurts the score and you can feel them going down.3.4.
A fine example of what we can buy in the States. Rich. Dark.  Malty. Strong body. Good beer.
quite a robust beer. the flavors of Belgian are part of this concoction. Aroma is hints of orange marmalade, many rich malts of mild cocoa, heavy fruit and light hop presence.

The aroma has caramel, toasted malt, spices (orange ginger), and yeast. The appearance is deep amber with a two finger head. There are lots of floating particles. Yuck. The flavor is complex and like the aroma. The palate is sticky but thin. The aftertaste is bitter and toasty. I am not a huge fan.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2010 Bottle cork & wire: Pours a hazy, deep amber with deep orange hues in the light. Tan head is initially enormous and falls to a consistant film which leaves a thick lacing. The aroma is pungent. Tons of Belgian malt layers and fruits. Syrup soaked prunes, green raisins, toffee, and figs. The flavor is sweet dark fruits. Enormous complexity of figs, maple soaked prunes, butterscotch sweetness, dark citrus notes to give a balancing subtle edge. It developes more with each sip, and became more enjoyable as it approached room temperature. Plummy notes and berry-like characteristics became more apparent with warming. Theres a light dryness in the smooth, slightly roasty toffeeish finish. An outstanding Belgian Strong Ale.

Bottle. Dark amber-brown beer with a nice cream colored head. Huge fruity aroma with some sweetness - berry, plum, date. Deep malty flavor with chocolate, caramel, and nuts and some fruitiness. Flavor lingers with some earthiness and yeastiness and oak. Very smooth, creamy mouthfeel that is surprisingly a bit lighter. Hides alcohol very well and is very drinkable.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2007 Bottle, pours a very cloudy light brown with a foamy head that dissipates to a thin line.  Lots of sediment, regardless of the careful storage and pour.  Nicely aromatic, with clove, spice, some dark fruit and very light caramel.  Taste is malty and yeasty as expected, with surprising smoothness on the palate, light carbonation, very interesting flavor profile throughout.  Good stuff!

Pours a copper/brown color with a large light tan head. A fair amount of sediment is visable in the glass. Pleasant aroma of yeast, spices, caramel malt, and bubblegum.  Body is full, with the right amount of carbonation.  Flavor is full of sweet, dark fruits.  Caramel, yeast, malt and wood round out the flavor.  Finish is  mildly tart.  The alcohol is very well hidden, just barely noticeable in the finish.  A very impressive beer.

I still think this is THE BEST BEER I HAVE EVER TASTED.  The color is fantastic--what a true beer should look like.  My buddy and I bought a few bottles of this at a local import beer store, brought them home, and served them up in large goblets.  The beer not only pours perfect, but the look and texture and bits of yeast make for a great look.  The taste is creamy, strong, and flavorful perfection.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2014 brown, with sweet trecely malt nose, with a sweet syrupy complex malt with a little tartness. The 9% could easily slip by you... Rerate 13/03/08. 4.2The protien thats common in these bottles is always a real disapointment... was maybe a bit too sweet this time but still very nice once sived. 4.2

 bottle at home Jan 2011 ... dark copper rather than brown ... sweet toffee malt nose ... quite fizzy ... juicy sweet malts ... little sherbert ... berry fruity ... cherries mostly ... light yeast ... ligth syrupy body ... 4.1

Bottle at home may 2014... Bbf 2010... Deep copper... Small tan head.. Soft toffee.. Light pine... Big berry... Light caramel suger nose... Light fizz... Lightest cardboard oxidation... Soft plum berries... Soft malts... A beer to relax into 3.9
Deep mahogany with large creamy beige head. Malty caramel aroma. Dried fruit with lots of sweet malts. full bodied.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2007 Poured deep red/brown color.  You could smell the malt on the pour.  I smelled a dried fruit/rasin smell as well.  Tastes of spices, with a mellow feel.  This is very drinkable and the finish is perfect.  This is a great beer.

Poured into a Trappist glass.  More head than liquid.  Light red color with an aroma that is sweet, fruity, and very yeasty.  Flavor is ultra smooth and fruity.  Very drinkable and refreshing with a nice mouthfeel.
Dark brown colored pour with nice thick head to it.  A sweet fruity aroma with a sweet spicy finish.  This was pretty damn good.
a sweet heavy aroma.  pours dark brown.  tastes ultra smooth and mature, with a nice spicy finish.
bottle. dark amber color. sweet dark fruit aroma. very sweet taste with lots of alcohol. yeasty and rich thick sweet flavour.

The color was extremely foggy, brown/amber with a good amount of floating sediment.  The head was thin, light beige, and fizzy.  The aroma was sour, citrisy, yeasty, and wine-like.  The palate was carbonated well.  The finish was bitter and warm.

I ended up rating these about the same, but all steady increases. This one poured a reddish brown with plenty of sediment, like the others. The head is thick, tan, creamy, takes its time going away, and leaves a thick lace when it does. The aroma is sweet, cherries, wood, alcohol, reminds me of a Flemish Sour. The flavor does too, aged cherries/fruit, alcohol, wood, musty. The palate is crisp and warm, very mellow. The finish is warm and sour/tart. Delicious.

Bottle: Poured a reddish brown amber with a thick off white head. The aroma was sweet fruit and floral. The taste was complex malt blend almost tasted like it was smoked and very rich finish. After a long search it seems this beer matched all my expectations.

25.4 oz bottle. Pours a cloudy golden yellowish-red with an white one finger head.  LOTS of sediment!  Very appealing sweet aroma of flowers, apples.  The flavor is dominated by malt, follwed by carbonation, sweet apples and cherries.  Nice warming on the finish with a bitter burnt wood aftertaste.  Great beer!

Im not sure of the age, but this bottle looks old.  Very nice aroma of sweet candied fruit, plum, carmel, belgian yeast, apples, and cherries.  Appearance is hazy orange/brown with a nice off-white head.  Flacors of cherry, oak, some peppery notes, brown sugar, and sweet roasted malt.  A very nice complex beer.

On draught at The Rake. Cloudy reddish brown, big cream head that fades with strong lacing. Very malty, loads of spice and apples. Also some pruneish flavours. Sweet but not cloying. Strong, but not overbearing. Not dry enough for my palete, but a well made, flavoursome, complex beer.

750 ml bottle
Thanks to hezron for bringing this to a tasting.  I was suprised to discover that it is not a Top 50 (or even Top 100) beer based on the bottle we opened.  Perhaps it was just an aberation but while still a very well made beer it does not do enough to stand out from the rest of the Belgian strong ales to make it one of the 50 best overall.  Still, I was glad to give it a try and would not turn it down in the future if offered.
Aroma / Appearance - A foamy billowing head settled into a half finger cover protecting the blood orange tinted body underneath.  The nose was very unusual - ginger and nutmeg stand out in a crowded field that also contains cherries, oak and a nutty profile.  It reminds me a little bit of Christmas.
Flavor / Palate - A peppery sensation floods the senses.  When that settles, it is succeeded by an oaky nutty feel.  The mouthfeel is dense and creamy but seems to lack something to put it over the Top into 4.0+ range.  This is enjoyable and very well made but just falls a bit short in the end.

750 ML Bottle. Poured out a reddish brown color w/a moderate off white head. Classic full, sweet, floral, aroma you would expect in a fine Belgian. Sweet initial flavor of raisons, dates, citrus, & rock candy. Comes thru to show a fruity malt finish which balances this beer off quite well. Deep complex multi level flavor you would expect in a fine Belgian & alcohol is quite well hidden. Long sweet finish. Very enjoyable-Id highly recomend it.

750mL. Spritzy Meyer lemon zested aroma and bold grains of paradise. Earthy and climatic. Lemon grass and white pepper show through. Unique. Amber orange pour. A saison-esque aura full of bold yeasty peppers and some glissandos of lightly oily wheat malt. Over juice browned bananas comes a touch of basil lead. Then a rush of ginger, mellowed with time and maybe some crystallization. More peppery phenols. Grains of paradise kepts drawing me back to an earht humid musk that lingers in the air like a stagnant tropical day. Ginger articulates as if it thinks its hanging out with Eccentric Ale. Maybe some maple syrup ebbs in. Palate smacks out with some cumin in the nose and touch of flaming fig. Light grassy bites reel in some balance. 9% well concealed. Delicious and unique, however maybe not a Top 50.

Bottle at t Hemelrijk in Hasselt. Impenetrable brown color, thick and very lacey head. I smell raisins in there, and other sweet, dried fruit. Buzzy mouthfeel doing that tongue-dancing thang. Sweetish taste of malt, fig, caramel, interesting! Lightly dry finish. Alcohol is subtle, as it should be.

Weird aroma!  Cola, coriander, orange, lemon grass, nutmeg, pepper, ginger, etc...  Heavily spiced and very aromatic, almost perfume-like.  Dark amber-brown in color with a few floaties and a thick, off-white head.  Flavor is a bit disappointing at first but then it grows on you.  Fresh, peppery, orange and ginger spiced flavor, lots of caramel and rich dark malt but not overly cloying.   Nice smooth and velvety mouth feel thats nice and drying.   I keep tasting a combination of spices that reminds me of cola.  Interesting, complex and easy to drink.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2013 Re-rate 4/21/13: Bottle from my cellar shared at kerenmks place. Best before 2008. Dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of chocolate, raisins, prunes, caramel and light oxidation. Sweet flavor with malt, caramel, dark fruits, a bit of chocolate, sherry notes and a bit of licorice and alcohol. Medium-bodied. Still pretty nice after all these years, but I think its better fresher. Score is not calculated. 7/3/7/3/14=3.4

Re-rate 7/12/10: Bottle from my cellar sampled at a tasting. Best before 2008. Like every time with Abbaye des Rocs, theres a big gusher when the bottle is opened. Hazy brown color. Aroma of dark fruits, caramel and a bit of vinous notes. Sweet flavor of malt, brown sugar, plums, cherry notes, a bit of berries and a bit of fruity acidity. Medium-bodied. Lighter in body and flavor than how I remember it, but still tasty and flavorful. 7/4/7/3/15=3.6

 Re-rate 4/22/08: Bottle. Best before 2008. Dark brown color with a big long-lasting beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, dark fruits, some roasted notes and some cocoa. Rich sweet malty flavor with plums and some prunes and raisins, mild spiciness and a bit of alcohol towards the finish. Rather full-bodied. Not a 4.7 like Ive rated it before but a really great one nonetheless. I need to try another fresh one someday. 8/5/8/4/17=4.2Re-rate 4/16/07: Had to add a point in "palate" and one overall. This beer deserves better than 4.5. It really is an amazing beer. 9/5/9/5/19=4.7
Bottle. Color is dark brown, with a a large beige head. A wonderful complex aroma, with sweet malts, caramel, raisin, and some more layers I cant put my finger on.
Great malty flavour with some hop bitterness, dark fruits, caramel and an alcoholic edge. Soft sweet finish. Full body.9/5/9/4/18=4.5

Dark fruits and sweet malt stands out in the aroma.Pours Dark brown with a reddish tint.Has a good sized tan head.Lots of flavor in this one.Dark fruits,sweet malt and a noticable alcohol presence.Full mouthfeel with a wine like finish.
lots of brown sugar and carmel with a little but of cherry and some apricot and nutmeg

Amber-hued brown pour with lively foam on top presents an equally vivacious nose of candied fruit, cinnamon, and sugared bread.   Palate has that excellent balance of heft and carbonation that is the signature of so many Belgians.  Flavor is rich and deep as well, with a marked fruit character that is restrained by a Flemish sour infusion.  Robust and rewarding this is around that upper echelon of Belgians.

Well, I have to kick myself a few times for making a rookie mistake. Ive tried to not let the numbers reflect the fact that a bad pour sent the yeast into suspension, causing a chunky mess to be poured, even in the first glass. My problem was due to the relatively long neck and my one-handed pour while holding my snifter-type glass in the other hand. This caused a bit too much forward lean on the bottle and a resultant glug-glug of air trying to get out of the too-full neck. The turbulence made for a messy beer. Nonetheless, this bottle obviously had a huge amount of sediment. Beyond that, my bottle was obviously past its prime, fairly vinous and oxidized. Despite this, there were some great caramel flavors, sweet toffee-like chewiness, a great, light-tan head, and other enjoyable qualities. Too bad I only had one bottle!

Served at cellar temperature in an oversized ballon-type wine glass. Pours a clear reddish brown with a good 3" of tan foam. The color changes to a somewhat orangy hazy brown (about the color of Lipton iced tea from the bottle) over time. The thick foamy lace lasts throughout. Thickest lace I can ever recall. Fruity malty aroma, with some sugary sweetness in there too. A scent of alchohol - maybe rum.

Slightly tart with a full malty flavor, a taste of dark stone fruit is in there, along with some fig and brown sugar. Something reminds me of the skins of dark plums. Subtle yet complex. Moderately hoppy, a bit more bitter than most Belgians, but not unpleasant. There is a bittersweet aftertaste around the edges.

750 ml bottle purchased early 06 sampled early 07.

Starts to foam out of the bottle and pours a hazy red-brown with a medium sized head (small, given the foaming upon opening) that is realtively short lived. When I look at the bottle 5 minutes later, foam is slowly oozing out, and continues to do so until I cap the bottle with a rubber stopper. 
 The aroma is very interesting - molassas and dates, plenty of ginger. The flavor is a rich and fascinating somewhat-sweet belgian ale, with dried fruit swirling around background hops, honey and lots of spice and creme brule and an ever-so-slightly sour hop finish. The mouthfeel is lovely, full-bodied but not oily or sticky, carbonated but not overly so, rich but not hot. 

All in all, its an excellent beer but perhaps not the world-beater that it could have been given that its ranked considerably higher than the astonishly good des Rocs grand cru and tripel imperiale.
wow........aroma of citrus, honey, and malt. mouthfeel is thick, and sweet. nice and sweet, full of dried fruit, excellent of of my fav belgians.

bottle donated from etowneraser--it pours a cloudy, what looks like sentement filed golden amber color.  It smells wonderful, lots of sweet citrus honey, and malt. tastes, malty very pleasant mouthfeel. but there is a metally taste to it that Im not to fond of. very sweet and fruity. plums or something and a bit tart at the end.

Bottle - 330ml. Cloudy terra-cotta body with yeasty chunks and a huge beige foamy head. Fantastic malty/hoppy aroma with fruity and vineous hints. Alcohol is very well hidden. Taste is sharp and perfectly balanced. It carries plummy and oaky notes, and ends with a long bitter/sour finish. Excellent choice fot my 900th rating!
Pours a hazy amber color with small tan head. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Malts. Citrus. Slight alcohol burn. Dry, bitter finish.
Very spicy, tremendously complex aroma. The flavor is also quite spicy with a nice malty sweetness.  Super.

Labelled Brasserie des Rocs. Enjoyed Xmas day with my father-in-law.  Poured with an occasional glop of something slimey coming out.  Hmmm.  I did drive it 90 miles but handled it carefully....  Mild malty sweet aroma.  Cloudy brown color with an orangey hue.  Peering closer there is a veritable soup of fluffy particulate matter suspended within.  Head dissipitates quickly.  Flavor is perfectly balanced, tangy, wonderful.  Mouthfeel is tingly, sweet on the front and mildy bitter at the end.  The occasional gelatanous glop (not quite ropiness) reminds me of a chinese egg drop soup.  I think I need to sample another bottle...
Pours a great head in a chalice, with a very sweet smell and taste...and you can really taste the hops..a great sipper

murky brown body with small brown head (quite a bit of sediment present)..aroma is strong in dark fruits, figs, caramel, sugar, toffee, nuts and marshmallow...flavor is of chewy malts, heavy in figs and raison, brown sugar, bread and biscuit with a touch of citrus hops in the finish..well done

2002 bottle from Kulminator. Slightly murky dark amber with a small almost yellow head,  a small chunk of yeast swam freely around the glass. Sweet fruity aroma, with some light dusty yeast and caramel, had some interesting vanilla musk too. The body was full, sweet and warming, with slight overcarbonation. Flavours of spice, yeast, toffee and whisky, fairly complex and enjoyable, not as sweet as the aroma would suggest. The finish was warming and fruity.

Bottle from trade with kmweaver . Thanks Ken! Pours a hazy reddish amber color with a huge frothy off white head. Aroma is intense and wonderful of malt, a variety of fruits, caramel and candy. Taste is very complex but smooth and slightly sweet. Lots going on with this beer. Has a hint of hops on th epalate but finishes with a delicate malt flavor.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2007 This one was great. Looked like a quadruple with dark red body and a thick-bubbled head. It had a sweet aroma with caramel, figs, raisins, sugar, vanilla and the bready malty twang that alot of the similar beers have. Great complexity. The taste was no surprise after the aroma, and it was very well balanced. Smooth mouthfeel as expected, not too much carbonation and very drinkable overall. Very good.

[Present from Finn, bought in Brussel]

Very complex fullbodied beer with lots of notes of various sweety ingredients. Also hoppy, but only to balance this very fine brew.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2007 BB 2008.  Pours an opaque, deep garnet-brown with floaties; head is moderately full, off-white, fizzy, but creamy, with decent lasting ability and some nice lace.  Aroma is sweet and fruity; brown sugar, nutty toffee, raisin, plum, a berry-like character that is unusual, and some burnt wood and spicy whisps of alcohol.  Flavor is of the same, brown sugar, plum, raisin, light berry notes, and burnt oak, with vanilla, as if from an oak-aged barrel.  Palate is soft to lively, nearly chewy and a bit syrupy with a medium-full body and a mild alcohol warmth.  Overall, its a bit too sweet and lacking the exceptional depth of the great Belgians.  Nice and enjoyable and worth the try, but nothing in comparison to the Grand Cru.  

After another try, I did like it better but still lacks the multiple layers of flavors and the numerous amounts of floaties detracts from the appearance and the palate.  The beer remains still a bit too sweet with the only note keeping it from being cloying, the burnt oak note which is not the most pleasant note.  Nice and quite unique but not one of my favorites of the style.

Sedimenty body, ruby colour, creamy white head.  Aroma is quite sweet, but no hint of candi sugar.  Mouthfeel is quite nice, alcohol is a little too evident, and the flavour is quite strong and hoppy.  I could wish for more malt to balance the hops and perhaps less alcohol.
Clear ruby amber body with a medium creamy off-white head. Very sweet hoppy aroma. Sweet malty flavor with some fruity hints and a touch of hops.

Pours dark reddish-brown with a rich head. Lage chunks of sediment in suspension. A very complex aroma of sweet malts and floral nectar. This brew has a mulitilayered flavour of malts and dried sweet fruit - strongly resembles floral notes of the fynbos nectar honey (fynbos is a small coastal brush growing in the vicinity of Cape Town ,South Africa). Awesome! Alcohol well tucked away. Silky mouthfeel and long flavourful finish with light bitterness that begs for more.  Fantastic beer!!

750mL bottle.  Pours a beautiful amber color, clear; off-white head with strong lacing.  Plenty of dried fruits and vinuous notes in the aroma, raisins and belgian sugar.  Medium-to-full, slightly chewy mouthfeel: lots of belgian sugar, hints of cotton candy, dried apricots, some citrus notes.  Tasty, but nothing to write home about; I prefer their Grand Cru.  Medium finish, raisiny and vaguely bitter, almost plasticy.  Like Italian wines (and a lot of the Ommegang beers), I feel like this is better to pair with a meal than to drink on its own.
Lots of stuff going on with this brew. Hints of caramel, raisins, and plums. Pour a nice deep brown with a frothy head to it.

On tap at Papago Brewing. Red/copper colored with no head by the time it got to our table. Aroma consisted of sweet malts, dark fruits, brown sugar, and a little yeastiness. Taste was extremely well balanced, very malty and fruity, even vaguely tart, without going overboard in any way. Amazingly smooth mouthfeel with just the right amount of carbonation. Also great with cheese and chocolate! Awesome.
perfect mouthfeel, nicely hopped, with citrus, honey, yeast and malt.  Incredibly ballanced, though I was expecting a little more structure and complexity.

This 750mL had both a bottle cap and a cork. Hazy copper color with floating sediment and thin tan head. Lots of carbonation but the head receded to a ring in a couple of minutes. Sweet soft aroma of caramel malts, dark fruit, brown sugar and something else I cant really describe. Smooth mild flavor that tastes as it smells. I get the cherry-date like fruitiness, some sweet caramel malts along with a hint of yeast spiciness. There seems to be a bit of orange citrus sweetness and a slight hint of wood that wasnt apparent in the aroma. Excellent beer.

Hazy dark amber hue, with a thick frothy beige head, leaving laces, with some big floaties of lees swirling around,  nice yeasty fruity nose, of ripe apples, with some nutmeg, cinnamon and coriander spiciness accents, with a toasted malt, and caramel malt note, coated in a candied orange peels aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty fruity character of ripe apples, raisins, dates, with a good spicy accent of cinnamon and coriander, and a smooth sweet mouthfelling of brown sugar, toasted malt, and cookie dough, when the beer gets warmer, a faint bouquet of provence spicy herbs seems to emerging, leading towards a sweet malty, and spicy subtle gentle hops bitterness finish.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2007 Nutty and spicey characteristics that dance with the seven types of malts that are used in this brew.  Impressive complexity upon the palate, wonderful aroma of the delicate European hops.  Such a delicate sensation as you swish it around your mouth.  Wonderfully sweet aftertaste that slowly releases to express the essence of the various hop and malt varieties.  Perfectly balanced beer that leaves one remarking how it plays with the senses.

Bottle.  Clear deep brown color with nice beige head and lots of big sediments.  Caramel, yeast and hops aroma.  Taste of malt caramel, metallic aftertaste, high carbonation and Big chunks.    

Bière de couleur ambré clair avec un bon collet beige et beaucoup de sédiments.  Odeur de malt, caramel et houblon.  Au goût, elle est ok, malt caramel mais, avec un léger arrière goût métallique et co2 élevé.  Par contre, les dépots sont beaucoup trop nombreux et surtout beacoup trop gros, on peut les sentir passer quand on prend une gorgée.
Nice thin creamy head, cloudy brown-redish body. Very sweet with fruity acidity. Also a very yeasty taste and lots carbonation.

BIg Bottle - too much for a light weight in an hours time on a week night - lights out.  That being said, a delicious beer.  Light brown with red highlights. Beautiful light brown head that sticks around.  Very distinctive flavor - sweet fruits, nutty, a hint of spiciness - a terrific balance.  Great feel in the mouth- smouth down the pipe.  A hearty beer - full body. Great beer with a meal.  My full rec.
750 ml bottle. Amber brownish color with beige  head. Lots of hops  Aroma has that dark fruity scent to it. . Excellent.
nutty, and some fruits i cant quite make out, spicy good aftertaste. very nice had at Joes in T.O. over a year ago

My best so far!  Aroma is tops, a hint of nuttiness with a nice hoppy/sweet paradox.  The head was large (good) but died a bit quickly.  Flavor, mmm,mmm best ever for such a strong brew.  Anonther sip and Im changing the 8 to a 9.   That good nutty darkness with a sweet fruity hint.  Wonderful on the palate as all good browns.  Send me something better, but I have a hard time thinking there is anything better in a bottle.

(Bottle at Monks Café, Stockholm) Pours hazy brown/red with big yeast flakes and a white head. Fruits, berries, allmond paste, yeast, wet tobacco, herbs and white pepper aroma with notes of ripe bananas. Some brown sugar. Spicey, a bit fiery flavour with lots of carbonation and some herbs. Small acid touch. Salty aftertaste with a small alcohol-ish afterbitterness. Prettty thick mouthfell.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2007 Bottle from a small trade with Jamie at Sams in Durham, NC.  Beautiful dark amber pour with a slight-off-white head. Lots of carbonation. Aroma smelled like a milder version of their grand cru, lots of fruits--citrus espically, heavy sugary malts, vanilla, cinnamon, yeast, faint hops, spices. Very smooth and tasty. So many floaties and sinkies, fuck filtration.  Tasty. Nice one to ring in #200 with.

Aroma was full of citrus, sweet and fruity.  Dark reddish orange color with plenty of sediment floating in the beer. Sweet flavor, full of malt and carmel like flavors.  Creamy in the mouth.  Very good overall.
Bottle. Aroma is on the small side, but flavor is of the scale, almost over the top. I need to have this one again.

Bottle 33 cl. Medium brown ambaries color. Medium head. Aroma is powerful, notes of port vine caramel / burned caramel. Hind of cherry. Some notes of malt, vanilla and hop, yeast. Flavor there are some sweet and bitter notes. Finish is smooth and very pleasing. A great beer that can compete with the best that Trappists has to offer I thought.

75cl bottle shared with mate: lovely aroma of plum and raisin with lots of malt and some spice.  pours a brownish read type color with a bubbly head that dissipates a few sips in.  Complex flavors of malt, some plum, raisin, spice, and just nice sweet mixture of alcohol and malt.  Sweetens as it warms.  Nice mouth feel that is full and not over active.  Excellent brew!
Deep brown amber with thick offwhite head. Cinnamon, caramel and vegetables. Quit sour actually but still a complex and balanced beer.
Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Unclear brown - offwhite head. A lot of fruits/berries, yeast, sweet, caramel, raisins, tobacco, chokolate, and a lot more....

Bottled. Sampled at Monks Café, Stockholm. Red-brown colour, with a beautiful fluffy foam. Sweet aroma, reminiscent of a flowery meadow. Maltsweet, with notes of banana, herbs and spices, with berry-ish tones and almond paste. No bitterness. Red apples. Big, complex flavour. Very enjoyableand perfect to sip slowly. The high ABV is hardly noticable. A good autumn beer.

Pours rust colored with a soupy opacity and weightless colloidal lumps barely visible through the glass. A billowing head of marshmallow fluff begets lacy fractals. Hypnotic aromas enshroud the senses, too numerous to catalogue. I shall make the attempt, nonetheless: jasmine and gardenias, cherry/blueberry, herbal-grassy hops, bubblegum wrapper, perfume, burnt caramel, new cigar, fig, vanilla, rum, banana a list by no means inclusive. The heady fragrance is so bewitchingly erotic that it reduces ones intellect to babbling incoherence. Articulating the savory whirlwind of ensuing flavors proves an equally baffling tasksweet and fruity, candylike, kiwi and chocolate, licorice, pie crust, rosemary, Meyer lemon, 7-up, allspice. Simultaneously uplifting and humbling. The beer crackles with random exploding bubbles as it passes the lips, and fizzes into a rich symphony of taste that osmoses into every surface of the mouth, tongue, and throat. Numerous gelatinous floc-blobs distract from an otherwise flawless texture. Flirtatious alcohol expresses itself as a blossoming glow of euphoria. The aftertaste, a mingled aura of spearmint, cocoa, and Lucky Charms, concludes this enchanting, almost spiritual, experience. Mesmerizing and ultimately satisfying; as thrillingly pleasurable as foreplay, goosebumps, and piss shivers.

750ml bottle picked up at Johns in Iowa City.  reddish amber with a fast shrinking tan head, disolves to a small ring of lace.  ( appearance would have been scored higher except for the massive chunks of floaties. )    aroma and flavor is multi-dimensional and complex with lots of dried fruit, sweet caramel and mild hops.  mouthfeel is full and soft without a ton of carbonation.  never did notice the alcohol, even after it warmed to near room temp.  very enjoyable
Pours a hazy amber/brown color with large creamy light brown head. Aroma is sweet and complex, cookies, pine, earthy, and flowery with a hint of cherries and red wine.
Bottle. Amber color with a big creamy mostly lasting head. Rich hoppy aroma with notes of malts and caramel.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a brownish amber murky color with a very thick and creamy beige frosty head.  Lots of hops floating around.  Aroma has that dark fruity scent to it.  Dates, nutmeg, figs,dark cherries and fresh yeast are present in the aroma.  Taste is lightly sweet with hints of figs,nutmeg,dates,brown sugar,malt and dark cherries.  Excellent.  Very similar to the Grand Cru by Abbaye des Rocs.
Wow.. Pretty much in agreement with the commercial description.. But it all comes together in the aroma... huge beer.

A cloudy, deep red-amber color, this has a sweet, fruity aroma. The flavor is not quite as sweet and yeasty as some of the top Belgians, but a very nice flavor, with a balance of malts, hops, and spice. Overall, greatly enjoyable.

I had higher expectations for this one as I had the Grand Cru recently and was pretty impressed with.  Comparatively, this one was not as sweet, much hoppier, and has a spicier and deeper aftertaste.  Very complex and tasty. Overall, an excellent brew.

Bottle at Frigo in Shinjuku, Tokyo.  Poured a dark, hazy/translucent brownish amber color.  Sweet, fruity, malty, nutty aroma... also had elements of dried fruits (cherries, dates, figs, raisins) and yeast.  Rich complex flavors of dried fruits, carmelized sugars, yeast, malts, just a touch of hops at the finish.  Its hard to believe that theres no added sugar in this brew.  Completely amazing, a truly awesome experience.
Dark reddish color with a thick head. The aroma of sweet fruits and the taste of caramel and also of yeast. You cannot taste that much of the 9% alcohol.I tis a nice berr to have over and over again.

beautiful brown red native anerican skin color brown red. meduim size fizzy short lived head like and no one likes that. smells like candied fruit and sour cherry. it tastes lovely. malt wood but a little short in the finish just a hint of alcohol. highly drinkable though. it has flavor and none of it is bad.

Clear amber body with ruby highlights and a pillowy, off-white head that fades to a lasting cover. Caramels, candi sugar, bananas, pears and golden raisins in the nose. The flavor is raisins, nutmeg, pears and candi sugar. Medium/full body with a rich velvety smooth texture.

Ruby color, some floaties I assume I did not pour it properly. As for the head, a perfect score, compact, creamy, sustainable, great carbonation. The nose is really fruity, reminds me of peaches in syrup, lots of esters, caramel and a whole lot more. A hint of sweetness, tangy/sour fruity acidity, and a long controlled elegant bitter finish. I was amazed how this beer manages to be quite bitter while this feature is never overwhelming. Not to mention a chewy sirupy body. Overall, and exceptionnal beer, comes close to Trappist standards in terms of complexity and balance.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2014 Taste this beer more times.
Deep hazy amber color., with lightbeige head. 
Aroma darkmalts and ripe fruit. 
Medium to full body.
Taste bit sweet, and darkmalts, fruits, good bitterness. An fantastic  belgian strong ale, 
Great brewer.

Bu dune 75 cl à la Fête Bière & Saveurs 06 (#1). Ça commence très bien ce festival. Belle couleur ambrée avec un peu de résidu, bon collet. Petit arome dépice plaisant. Très bon goût de malte de caramel sucré, bonne sensation chaude mais pas alcoolisé.

Bottle from Secret Santa (thank you) Pours a red/brown color with a prolific head that lasts forever (you will finish this beer and then want to drink the remaining foam). Aroma is complex, fruity, sweet with caramel and cooked plum, raisin and fig. You could spend an hour smelling this beer and still find new things with every wiff. Flavor is equally complex and malty with a touch of wood that was not presant in the aroma. Absolutly wonderful, subtle, refined yet strong and dominating beer.

Pours a brown/ orange nice white head. Really dont see what makes this one any better than a lot of other trappists styles just like this but cheaper. Your basic brown sugary sweetness, caramel, dark fruits, some apple, alcohol isnt noticeable and this is a good beer but I just dont see what seperates it from many others.

330 ml bottle from B.C. Liquor store. Pours a medium brown colour with a lingering rich head.  Deep, dark plummy-raisin notes dominate the nose and carry through into the flavour. Distinct caramel notes at first that end with dark toasted Munich malts. Very complex and inviting. Even at 9.0% I could drink a lot of this decadent brew!

750 ml bottle.  Nice light brown color.  Aroma is of lightly smoked wood with fruit.  Taste of light berries (raspberry, blackberry family of fruits) with nice malty-yeast undertones and a light smoky taste too.  Sweetness is very light and pleasant, not overdone.  Finish is very pleasant with nice and light tingly hop taste/feel.  9%!?!  Hard to believe this is so strong given the feel.  This one gets better the more you drink.  Not my typical style, but I really do like this one!

Bottle. Poured a light brown with somewhat opaqueness and a small tan head. Intense scents - grapes, alcohol, yeast, caramel, chocolate. Despite the commercial description I feel this beer has more of a white wine character as it has omnipresent fruit and dry palate. It has a wonderful full-body to it with a somewhat sweet and yeasty mouthfeel. Excellent. Has characters of a tripel.

750. bottle. poured beutifully with nice carbonation and formed nice rocky head. brown with red hues. spcey malt aroma with hints of cola. Sweet caramel begginning  with dark cherries and dried fruit quickley gives way to mellow hop spice and dark sugar with a nice complex yeast character.

big 750 mL bottle.  dark cherry-brown color with tons of floaties - despite a careful pour into two glasses, an enormous amount of sludge made it into the second glass.  unappealing yes, but im still going to drink it.  primary an alcoholic brown sugar aroma, but also earth caramel, and some salt-like yeasty tang.  sweet winey flavor with a more balanced finish; caramel apple and woody notes - traces of molasses float around.  the 9% is barely detectable with most presence in the aroma - overall very good but all that sediment really detracted.  very much like a barley wine fermented with a belgian yeast.

Very dissappointed in this, considering its status and price ($11, 750). Bottle is best by 2008, so Im guessing this is a 2005. I almost wonder if the quality of my bottle was a little off, considering other (top raters) ratings of this brew, although recent ratings are quite a bit lower. Aroma is restrained, plum/sugar/zucchini/alcohol, unassertive and quite boring. There is maybe a touch more complexity and punch in the flavor, with a richer taste reminiscent of other "belgian barleywines," slightly sweet under the funky fruity malts and belgian yeast. Pour was also pretty sad, with a big head that is gone within seconds. More flavors include leather, asparagus, some mild spicy hops, vanilla icecream.
750 ml bottle. from Downeast Bev Co. in portland. deep hazy amber color. aroma of malts and ripe fruit. similar flavor. an exelend belgian strong ale, but i still think i perfer Gulden Drak

330ml brown bottle from HogTownHarry, much thanks sir! It poured hazy orangey brown, various floaties. Full thick tan head. Aroma is malty, spicy, chocolatey and yeasty, also some fruitcake notes. Rich malt flavour with some cocoa. Rummy, warming finish with some dryish woodiness, yeast and cherries. Softly carbonated, medium bodied.

750 ml bottle: Thanks to my Secret Santa, I was able to enjoy this one with my wife tonight.  It has a murky brown color with a stiff light brown head.  It has aromas of yeast, mild bananas, spices like nutmeg, homemade apple cider and fermented peaches.  The taste is quite sweet - dates, figs, wheat, alcohol.  Generally, a little sweet for me.  The body is full (borderline syruppy), smooth and creamy leaving a slight, tingly alcohol burn in the aftertaste.  A robust and complex Belgian strong.
750ml bottle-pours a tan head with cloudy brown color.  Aroma is medium/dark malt, fruit.  Taste is medium/dark malt, sweet, fruit-apple, secondary hops.  Good carbonation.

From a capped, corked 750 ml. green bottle with no bottled/freshness date, sampled at cellar temperature in a chalice.

Poured a slightly hazy reddish amber with a foamy head that settled into a thin lacing.

Aromas of plums, tart cherries, caramelized sugar, honey and freshly baked pastry.

Good Belgian carbonation and a softly crisp, smooth lightish medium bodied mouthfeel.

Tart cherries, cinnamon, candied sugar and honey, cookie spices, almonds towards the end, a subtle sweet maltiness and a dryish tart cherry and sweet spicy finish, good drinkability.

A nice and tasty Belgian dark ale, well worth trying.
Bottle. Amber colour with a huge creamy mostly lasting head. Rich hoppy aroma with notes of malts and caramel. Full palate.
Bottle. Courtesy Niels Jørgen at Wintercoat. Creamy white excellent fully lasting head. Amber colour. Heavy hopy aroma. Nice bitter/sweet flavor. A little acetic. Long finish. Oily palate.

750. Mostly clean sample. Beer is a murky medium-brown copper-caramel color with a huge, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing head. 
First impression on the nose is earthy, citrusy and sweet. Lovely. Its malty with light notes of toasted bread, moderate notes of cookie, caramel; Hoppy with moderate notes of herb and lemon, light note of minty floral; Yeasty with light notes of soap, basement, trace of sharp cheese; Miscellaneous notes of moderately weighty orange zest. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lightly-to-moderately acidic/dry with a long, lightly acidic/dry, moderately warm, lightly-to-moderately sweet, lightly bitter finish. Palate is lush, matches warm, aroma. The body is medium, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is fizzy. Gorgeous to the core.

Bottle (from Bitter Virtue). Despite leaving the bottle for about a month undisturbed and carefully removing it from my cellar there was a good inch worth of loosely adherent solid matter clustered around this base. Upon pouring I couldnt even get one clean glass worth, but enough about the sediment. Strong fruity aromas with a little toasty malt, spice and slight alcohol. Fairly sweet with a little bit of hop to balance and intrusive metallic yeast. The actual beer itself seemed quite good just not quite right, which I put down to the mass of yeasty? or proteinaceous? gunk

Corked bottle, which I found out later may be old. I will rerate, but I need to keep my notes here to be sure. Pours red, with a sparkling champagne type carbonation and a creamy off white head that retains well. Aroma of tart cherries. Flavor of tart fruit and chocolate, but with no sweetness. The strange acidic finish had hints of oxidation. I need to revisit this one.

Pours a deep brown color with lots of floaties. Huge tan head. Strong complex aroma full of dark fruits and chocolate. Hints of toffee and almonds as well. Each sip seems different. Fruity chocolatey, sweet but bitter at the finish. Truly an outstanding beer.

"This is one fine brew. The des Rocs Brune pops open and gushes out of the bottle a bit. The head is massive when poured and has decent retention. Aromas are vinuous, sweet malt, and dark fruits. A very pleasant aroma for sure. The flavor is great. Tastes of sweet malt, butterscotch, caramel, figs, with just a very slight bitterness in the end. Very complex in my opinion. THe mouthfeel is a real pleasure too--just thick enough to make this one satisfy.

pours nice amber with bubbly off white head.  Aroma is bready and sweet.  Some wood.  Taste is sweet with some fruit notes.  Nice woodsy sweet flavor.  Easy on the palate.  Layers of nice flavor in the finsh.  Sweet and bitter that lasts.  Excellent.

Lovely amber with ruby tones.  Brief white head.  Lots of malt and yeast in the aroma at first, then a sense of fruit comes through.  Oranges and some sour apples.  Well carbonated and great on the palate.  Tastes of bread and oranges.  I wish I had another bottle.

750. Pours dark brown with a rich, dense head that sticks around for a while. Intense green apples permeate the nose and palate. Plenty of other fruit, sweet malt, some sugar. Overall, the apples were a disappointingly overwhelming addition to the mix, but this is still an amazing beer--just imbalanced in the direction of tartness.

750 mL bottle coutesy of tjthresh.  Pours cloudy nut brown with a frothy tan head that diminishes to a patchy and edgy film.  Aroma is sweet caramel malt (cookie), yeast (earth, dough), alcohol, vanilla and port notes.  Medium sweetness, bitterness and acidity, nutty caramel malt flavor, yeast and a slight sourness, alcohol at the end.  Medium bodied, fizzy and foamy palate.

light brown with a big tan head, heavy carbonation.  Aroma is sweet malty bread, alot of dark fruit.  Taste is fairly complex, with raisiny fruit, caramel, wood, vanilla, and earthy, spicy notes with a slightly bitter finish.

Magnificent beer, I tasted it at the zythos beer festival! And I immediatelly bought a couple of bottles :D What can I say more ;) Magnificent taste, very fruity (not too! fruity)

Try it!
UPDATED: APR 1, 2007 tons of dark fruit.  a bit of alcohol.  quite beautiful in an opaque red/brown combo.  head doesnt leave ever.  tastes pretty good, but i cant make a decision here.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2006 Bottle. Dark caramel color with a white-yellow head.  Great aroma with notes of alcohol and orange peel. Very mild flavor with a fleeting bitter finish and an almond undertone.  Great mouthfeel; not too thick or thin and perfectly carbonated.
Bottle.  this one was wonderful.  one of the best belgians ive tried (not too many... yet).

33 cl bottle. Yeast at the bottom. Brown colour with a frothy white head. Lovely smooth aroma of yeast,caramel, sweetness, chocolate and light roastness, very complex. Fantastic flavour of smooth yeasty, caramel, roastedness, spices, honey very rich and smooth complexity. Very nice and amazing. I love it.

Pours a hazy garnet brown with lots of yeast floating around and a huge tan head.  The aroma is wonderful - lot of fruits and very floral.  There are also hints of molasses, honey, hazelnut, and chocolate chip cookies.  On first sip, there is an explosion of flavors on the palate.  From a delicous malty taste of honey and cinamon raisin bread to a spicy hops taste, this beer is one of a kind.  There are so many complex, rich flavors - its almost like a fine wine.  Definitely ranks up there with the best belgian ales in the world.

Best before 2008 (batch 5912?). Poured a nice red orange color with sedimentation on the bottom and a nice head that sustained itself well (bottle had some pop when opening). Aroma was very pleasant, somewhat floral (roses) with lighter fruits, yeast, and spices coming through. The flavor was all of that (apples and cherries mixed in with the darker fruits) with a touch of bitterness in the finish. Mouthfeel was carbonated and moderate but not thick.
Wonderful stuff. Served at about 50ª, the aroma and flavor are out of this world.

Malt and black forest cake aroma,reddish brown color with a million sea monkeys floating around, a sight that never scared me,big brownie mix dough mixed with a touch of anise and chocolate chip, a very different yet very enjoyable sweetness. Truely magnificant lacing. Aftertaste reminds me of the chocolate soda floats I had as a kid in the drug store. If they could step up the body and flavor level just one more notch,we would have a 5 here

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2006 Medium brown with a lasting head. The aroma is Caramel yeast and wood.  Full bodied, very rich and malty with some sour notes, sweet with apples, muscat grapes, rummy, dark dried fruits and brown suger. Truly an amazing beer.

From 750.  Dark ruby pour with tan head.  Tons of yeast in the glass, couldnt help it!  Highly carbonated.  Nose is bready, dark fruits, brown sugar.  Flavor follows nose and is a little chewy.  Fantastic beer, but basically the same as the Triple and Grand Cru.

750 bottle.  Not sure why, but this bottle was a gusher and a half.  I think I lost about half the bottle to the counter, floor and sink.  But what I was able to save, I enjoyed.
Pours a deep amber/burgundy which is topped by a thick off white head with a good amount of lacing left behind.  The aroma is sweet, malty and caramelly with a very slight flowery note, some fruitiness and the slightest touch of alcohol. The malty flavor is sweet and fruity with notes of caramel and the slightest touch of alcohol.   Full bodied, surprisingly smooth and slightly warming.

Thanks to gputty for sharing this during our Des Rocs tasting. 750 bottle. Hazy golden brown with a ton of floaties. Fruity, yeasty nose, dark fruits mostly. Sweet flavor, certainly yeasty, more fruit. Sweet malt and caramel round out the palate. Very, very good.

12 oz bottle huge thanks to blankboy for this EXTRA.  Pours hazy brown with little floaties.  Huge aromas of caramel, plum, raisin, chocolate milk, nutty malts.  Flavors reamin sweet with an alcoholic middle.  The finish is more malts.  Roasted and caramel.  More dark fruit and a touch of left over alcohol.  Delicious.  Wonderful Stuff.

Absolutely incredible. One of the best beers Ive had. Intense from start to finish. Pour is a beautiful chestnut brown. Aroma is malty heaven of wood, earth, plums, figs, raisins and fruity. Mind blowing. Flavors of molasses, burnt sugar, caramel and said fruits. Overall an excellent beer. Cant wait to get this again!! Im hooked!

Bottle.  Color is copper-orange, with significant material.  Thick white-tan head that last and last.  Aroma is tart, with some fruit and spiciness.  Lots of fruit--plums and raisons.  Sweet malty character upfront, but finishes dry.  Spicey phenols present, similar to what youd taste in a trippel are present.  Medium body.  Overall, a very interesting beer.  Hits the style dead on.

In the 750 mL bottle. Pours opaque brown with red and gold highlights. Has a dark beige head. Outstanding aroms-like a spring walk in the woods. Earthyness, plum, pears, honeysuckle, and raspberry fruit smell. Tastes not unlike Nastursium. Very interesting spices to this flavor. Brown, brown, brown. Subltle bitterness. Raisins. This is a strong beer without seeming to be. Thick and chewey, but has a subtle heat. A bit of bittersweet chocolate. The pronounced sweetness is well-balance with the spices and giant bolus of complex flavors. Finish is a bit dry and chalky.

Hazy deep amber pour complemented by a big effervescent off white head. Molasses, some dark fruit and spice in the aroma. Medium/full body that has a wonderful mouthfeel of rich and creamy malt. Many malt flavors present: caramel, molasses, raisin, nuts, earth. Hops come through in the finish with a mild bitterness, and some spice and herbal flavors. Wonderfully complex, rich, and satisfying.

Gushed an rocky, off-white foam that complemented my tan countertop well.  The body is a medium/dark mahogany color.  Aroma ia dark cherries, candied malts, and molasses.  Flavors were mostly molasses with some carmel, rock candy, and some mustiness.  Didnt really live up to my expectations.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2009 Dark amber coloured with a lot of big flakes of yeast. What a wonderfull aroma, sweet with all kinds of spices and fruits. Excellent flavors in it, yeasty, very sweet and a bit spicy. Brown sugar, a bit caramel, roasted, nice malts and a fruity finish. This is a very nice, well balanced, beer.
Re-rate: ow what a nice beer!

Aroma is kind of sweet cake toasty with mild spices. Light, cloudy brown in color with a huge fluffy tan head. Taste some black licorice, strongly, in the fore. Also get some darker fruits and brown sugar and some camalized sugar flavors. Has a toasty quality to it I hadnt expected. That strong and lingering licorice flavor was also unanticipated. There is a slightly spicy/hot alcohol note int he finish that reminds you this isnt just some crazy licorice tasty cake in liquid form, but a high abv beer.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours a hazy bronze color with an large off-white head. Aroma of spices, fruit, and alcohol. Flavor is smooth, sweet, spicey.

First bottle great, 2nd bottle too much setiment.

 3rd bottle  same too much setiment, Stegosaurus, used coffee filters to sift out the setiment and saved the brew.

Pours amber with a thin tan head. Aroma of yeasty esters with notes of bubble gum, plums, raisins, and cherries. Taste is sweet and yeasty, phenolic notes of apples and slightly malty notes of toffee. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with slight stickiness and lush Belgian carbonation.

Thanks to TomDecapolis for this...
Appears a hazy amber brown with a small white head that slowly fades out.
Smell is of sweet, sugary hard candies, caramel, traces of tropical fruit, and musty yeast.
Taste is of the same aromas but it comes together nicely in the mouth, making for a nice Belgian brew.
Mouthfeel is sugary, musty, and smooth along the tongue.

Pours a hazy brown amber with large floaties and an average bubbly head that laced.  Aroma of dark fruits, candied sugar, garpes and green apple.  Flavor of yeast, dark fruits, slight roastiness, more candy sugar and a little dry. Really liked this.

Bottle.  Fizzy and chunky.  The aroma is full of fruity notes and alcohol.  The body is very heavy with lot of malt.  Since Im not much for wheat beers, this Belgian is more to my style.  The alcohol comes through a bit too much though.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Bottled. Poured dark brown, with a rocky head. Malt and fruit in the nose and flavor, a very complex taste and a nice alcohol note to the finish. A true "100" of a beer.

1 pint 9.4 oz bottle labeled brasserie des rocs.  large frothy head on this heavily chucky brown beauty.  sweet fruit to the nose, taste is dry with complex fruit notes (both bitter and sweet).  nicely done, glad i grabbed this one.

Deep hazy coppery brown, fluffy light tan head.  Complex nose of fig, golden raisin, pear, brown sugar, and cotton candy, with soft undertones of dates and apricots.  Rich dark fruit flavor throughout, slight toasted brown sugar and apricot medley at room temp, and a soft hop bitterness pulls it together late.  Medium to full bodied, moderate carbonation, lightly bitter, soft dark fruity finish.  Just a great brew all around.  Dont pass this one up....

Aaarh the beer that took me into that fabled top 100 group of raters . I wanted something to honour the occasion and I thought that this would be appropriate. This is a 33cl bottle I bought at Noel Cuveliers farm and beer shop on the Belgian/French border on a Sunday morning in March. A rich ruby in colour with lasting beige head and some rather large floaters. A rather wonderful aroma.  Rich fruits but also grapefruity hops as well. Full and rich in the mouth with more strawberry and grapefruit with a dry hoppy finish that contains some residual red berry fruit sweetness as well as citrus grapefruity hop. A wonderful blend of rich malt fruit and tantilising hop. Excellent beer.
UPDATED: MAY 8, 2006 Awesome nose on this beer, pours very dark, spicy licorice/dark fruit/toffey flavours. My personal favourite of the belges ive tried. Very highly reccommend.

Bottle.  Sugary fruit aroma.  Dark murky copper color, with a large off white head.  I absolutely love this stuff!  This is just as good as Rochefort 10, but a better deal.  It is about the same price $8-$9, but you get a big bottle 1 pint and 9 or so ounces versus 11.2 ounces.  The only negative is the protein chunks, but I can get past that, no problem whatsoever.  Even my buddy whos not a belgian lover, said this would be one belgian that he wouldnt have a problem drinking.  This is pure gold!

Burgandy, murky orange.  Very lively and effervesce.  Black currant, dark plum sweetness, a tart berry wine fruitness, and oaky whiskey.  A complex maltiness.  Just the right amount of alcohol presence. Finishes with a pleasant dryness.  This is a fantasic brew.
Bottle 330ml. Appearance: Amber with white head. Aroma: Grapefruit, caramel malt, spices. Flavor: dark fruit, caramel malt, hoppy. Thank Harry.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2013 25.4 oz bottle.  Murky amber brown with a creamy bone head; leaves some lacing.  Nose of apricots and dried fruit; changes to banana and melon after a taste.  Flavor of soft candied fruits, rum and wood.  Assertive but not overpowering.   Medium body finishes a little tart with just a breath of alcohol.  Best balanced of the top 3 ADRs and one of the best beers Ive had.
UPDATED: DEC 9, 2010 Amber with a white head. Grapefruit, dried fruits, licorice and malt aromas. Sweet, quite simple flavour of caramel, dark sugar and fruit, with a dry finish.

Pours a beautiful dark brown with a nice sized head that diminishes quite slow.  The aroma is of dark fruits (dark cherry? figs?) and the earthy Belgium yeast.
The taste has a velvety mouthfeel with the dark fruit on the smell and maybe a bit of passion fruit.  Hints of carmel / toffee are in the background.  Carbonation is in the medium / high catagory.  Further down the bottle the mouthfeel gets a bit thicker, the dark fruits and alcohol become even more apparent.  Alcohol is never in the foreftont, but hard to completely hide at 9%.  Another excellent beer from one of the top breweries.  Highly recommended.

Dont understand all the chunky comments.  I buy mine the day before I will drink them and give them time to settle.  Anyways,  Classic color and head.  The alcohol, as in all of this breweries beers, is well concealed and works well with the rich caramel and nutty flavor. The earthy hops border on citrus and remain on a light lemon-grass that lingers with the brown sugar and toffee finish.  Clean and snappy on the end and I want another.

Best by 2007. Dark amber/brown. Fully chunkified. Cant stop the chunk. Heyyy yoouu guuuyyys! Huge, frothy, tan head. Aroma of burnt caramel, pungent past ripe fruits, doughy yeast, rich malt, subtle anise, spices. Same flavors, complex. Balancing hops make themselves known, also. Smooth, medium body is very chewy. I like the texture and chewiness, but the body would benefit from more weight. Overall a great brew. Possibly top 50. Their Tripel Imperial is easily their best. Id also put the Grand Cru ahead of this one, but not by much.

750ml - BB2007 - Aroma is strong, raisin, Belgian yeast, candi sugar, milk chocolate, and spice.  Pours brown with medium cream colored head and great lacing.  I had to subtract one for the amount of floaties in the first pour!  Flavor isnt as complex as the aroma.  Dark fruits, Belgian yeast, with sweet hints of chocolate.  Palate is smooth and creamy.  A great brew, but the floaties were too distracting for my complete enjoyment.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2006 Bottle: Pours with a red brown colour and a small creamy head. The aroma is burned malt, dried fruit and with yeast notes. It has a  smooth sweetness. Medium to full bodied. Flavour of malt, brown sugar and with a moderate hoppy finish. 
A enjoyable beer.

A rich, complex beer full of fruit and nut qualities.  Big mouthfeel.  Rich maltiness.  Increases in complexity as the beer warms and develops an even bigger mouthfeel that remains uncloying.  A great brew, indeed.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2006 Belgian Burgundy Ale. I can recognize the quality of this beer but it is not my thing.  There is a huge malt nose with light fruit, and more malt in the sweet flavor.  But there is another odd, sweet flavor to this beer.  I dont think it was from having an older bottle because it is a flavor I recognize from their other beers but didnt work out so well in this one.  The yeast strain, maybe?  But this is a very well made beer.  It looks great; dark red and lots of sediment as well as a thick and long lasting head.  Very heavy palate.  I do have a newer bottle and will give it another try.  -------- 2006 labeled as Brune this time.  This beer was as gusher and I lost some it it when opened.  Few beers have as much sediment as this.  Still underwhelmed with the simple flavor and aroma and lack of complexity in either.  It doesnt have enough going on to be scoring so highly.  Sweet malt, some light fruit, and that is about it.
Bottle. Off-white creamy head. Unclear dark red body. Lemon and grass aroma with alcohol notes. Bascially sweet flavor of berries I cannot distinguish. Strange but not bad. Still too sweet for me.
Bottle.  Brandied PlummP raisin, candy brandied pork & carrots, flavor packt molasses. pork n beans. cinnamon maple. pagan spices.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber hue with a huge, rocky beige head. The aroma has tons of raisin and plum, some sweet chocolate notes, dark honey, and earth. Wow, the flavor is delicious. At first it is pine, raisins, caramel, and pistacchio. Then a nice, woody yeast tone takes over; it reminds me of freshly baked raisin bread, but with a distinct, sharp citrus twang over it. The finish is just a little bit dry and ashy, and quite vinous. There is also a distant aftertaste of chicory and bergamot orange. It also leaves a spicy tingling on the tongue for a few seconds. The mouthfeel is full, yet bubbly. The best part, though, is the harmony between all of these elements. Really, separating them doesnt do the beer justice. I am very very happy about this one.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 Murky copper pour with short, off-white head. The aroma is sticky sweet with a slight barley wine smell  leathery and earthy. The flavor is fruity highlighting raisins and plums. Nicely sweet. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Creamy mouthfeel yet it avoids being cloying. Outstanding balance and a real delight to drink.
Rerate: Not as complex as I experienced the first time around. The fruitiness was more muted, a bitterness more forward. Still very good, but not as good as I originally rated it.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2006 Fiery amber pour with a great, fluffy head.  Tons of yeast particles in suspension.  Funky aroma is real barnyard and almost sour, but is cradley by a marmalade sweetness.  The body is overrun with overripe bananas - with more subtle notes of oak and strawberry coming forth in the finish. The flavors coat the tongue with a great, creamy mouthfeel.  This is extremely complex and keeps changing from start to finish - a real nectar.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2007 This thing has a bit of stank on it.  Some woodiness.  Low level fruitiness.  Poured an deep auburn color with an impressive head.  This thing is all about subtlety.  Nothing really stands out.  There is a definite woody character.  Very fully yet silky body.  I wonder what this beer tastes like a bit fresher.  Rerated on 4/22/07:  Still an outstanding beer.

25.4 oz corked bottle.  Cloudy reddish brown body with a big off-white head that didnt last long.  Aroma of champagne, peaches, and some alcohol.  Complex sweet flavor with notes of champagne, red wine, peaches, apples, grapes, and plums.  Almost chewy on the palate.  Very nice beer.

Wow this is some tasty shit.  Pours a rich brown with a sizeable fizzy head.  Aroma is a great bready malty sweetness.  Taste is similar...with a really good sense of that sweetness from fruit and honey.  Mouthfeel is smooth and a bit warming from the alcohol.  This one was fresh...I cant wait to try one that has been aged a bit.

Pours a lovely ruby-brown. Creamy tan head that diminishes to a thin film with lots of sticky lacing. Tons of yeast floating in there is the only reason I deducted a point for appearance. Aromas of dark fruits, wine, touch of alcohol and honey, just wonderful.
Flavor matches aroma with a hint of wood and just enough alcohol showing through for warmth. Mouthfeel is moderately creamy with a fair amount of carbonation. Finishes sweet and fruity with just a hint of bitter and alcohol.
This is an amazing brew, one of my favorites. I just wish it had less alcohol so I could drink it all night!
"Poured a red orange color with some sedimentation a nice head. Aroma was floral, yeast and light fruits. Flavor was of yeast and the lighter fruits. Mouthfeel was carbonated. Good beer."

Really great Belgium Bruin. Brown with a bid of a red Hew. I´ve tasted a 2002 edition this Christmas(2005) and it had developed its sweetness perfectly. Strong,sweet and fruity at the same time. This one is different from a lot of the other Belgium "bruins". The smell and finish is its own style. Very original.
